Table for two in the corner was quaint and perfect for us  while I went to freshen up my heart decided he needed yet another cocktail so he ordered a 22ox southern tier ( I guess that bottle of wine was out !!!!)  I opted for a glass of the Nero Diavlo which superb ive was been to the Tuscany region of Italy and this wine brought me back.
We glanced over the menu and though a Valentines Day feature prefix was offered we opted for two pizzas. The Shorty - Amazing short ribs, caramelized onions and cheese!!! what more could you ask for and the Spinach pretty standard but extremely flavorful I think it had to do with the béchamel that they use mmmmm. Our server was the only one working and he did the best he could. As the night went on more tables came and we saw a little less of him but he acknowledged us every time he walked by and kept water full and cleared away plates as needed. We didn't do desert and the damage was only 50.00 not incl tip... that's my kind of Vday dinner.

So I've been here twice now.  This last time was better than the first!  The first time I went there was not live music.  I do not know if that is a scheduled thing that you'd know about if you went there often enough or if it was just a pop up but it was awesome!  It made it feel a little bit like New Orleans.  A really rad addition to some fantastic food!

Before I even went there I was smitten with the appeal.  The Dart and Camaro that can be seen with arrows showing you the way and the Jerry's logo spray painted on the doors are a fantastic use of advertising dollars.  It really adds to the allure of the place.  My only qualm would be that the barricade jacket on front street is not fitted to the barricade.  So happens my company produces barricade jackets...so maybe next time I'll leave my card.  I really love the inside of the place.  From the sign outside to the rustic feel inside.  It's cool that it's in a kinda hidden spot as well.  I'm sure the cars are enough to draw interest and get you to look it up.  

I can hang with any place that sell La Colombe coffee. The food here is Stellar.  I cannot remember what I ordered the first time but this time i got the Eggs Jerry which is Smoked salmon, poached egg, caper dill hollandaise, potato latke.  I did not memorize that, I copied and pasted.  It was delicious and just the right amount of food.  However next time I'm def getting what My GF had.  The Taylor pork roll & scrapple sandwich.  I tried two bites and it was awesome.  
I'd love to try this place for dinner since the Brunch is so fantastic but I only ever seem to end up there on weekend brunchy days. As of right now this is my favorite brunch spot in Philadelphia.  I really don't think this place will disappoint anyone who enjoys breakfast items but is too lazy to get up before 10 AM.

*Also They took one of the photos of my Dog's instagram(not mine, his) in front of the Jerry's Camaro and put it up on the wall.  Which was really cool coming from such a great restaurant!  I didn't get to see it in person but a friend snapped a shot and sent it to me.

ANYWAY I'VE SAID TOO MUCH.  No one reads reviews this long.  GO HERE.

Love this place! Very small but sooo worth it. The first time I went and ordered pizza and wine. Amazing wine selection and knowledgeable bartender. Gourmet pizza was so good, I special ordered one with goat cheese, motz, mushrooms , spinach and tomato. They forgot the mushrooms and felt so bad about it they gave me free dessert which I didn't even ask for. It was a rich chocolate fudge cheesecake with fudge topping. Absolutely amazing!  First impression was awesome, even after they messed up my pizza! 

So I went back another time and the service was wonderful on a packed Fri night.  The lady at the door told me who was paying their bill at the bar seats, so I knew who to stand behind and grab their seats first when they got up. How helpful!!  Wine amazing, super friendly staff, and amazing gourmet pizza. The sweet potato gnocchi is also delicious. And prices are really affordable, especially for center city.  I will always come back to zavino!

Di Bruno Bros is a nice medium sized gourmet market. The moment you walk in, it's eye popping. So much looks so good. Their foods are very fresh. They have specialty items that are hard to get elsewhere.

The service here is like a top notch restaurant. You do not need to spend much time inside before being approached and asked if you need help. Something you surely would not get at your typical supermarket. But this is not your typical supermarket. I would not recommend for your every day grocery shopping, as it's more of a specialty place you go to get compliments to your other groceries.

Also, unless you like to spend a lot, this is not where I would go often. Like many gourmet markets, you pay for the quality.

The idea of trendy pizza place makes me nervous... surprisingly, Zavino is not douchey. Hurray. Their creative pizzas are respectably inexpensive.  

Get over here fast, they are giving out wine while their liquor license is pending! 

Hopefully they get a handle on the extreme heat that radiates from the oven to the seating area.

This place is awesome and deserves praise! The staff here is very friendly, and the menu has some fun ice cream names! I got a Nutella shake, and it was freakin' delicious! The shake had chunks of Nutella in it, and I hope to try the sundaes once. This is a great addition to Philly and I hope to go here again!

Damn good ice cream. I guess the name brand is what's so popular. I loved my Mermaid sundae., which had the perfect amount of lemon and pie crust... It literally tasted like a delicious refreshing lemon meringue pie. However, over $6 for the sundae which wasn't even a very large portion is too steep. But looks like people are paying it so who knows. It was delicious, but I don't understand the price.. Is it organic? No preservatives? Home made? Those things drive higher prices so then it would make more sense.. But maybe I'm just not informed. 

The staff was super friendly, and the line moved quick, so they have a great operation going.  But $7 for a milkshake? Ouch. I'll be back though.. I live next door and am obsessed with ice cream so of course I took the frequent buyer card!

4.5 stars, rounded up to 5.

Do you have $35 (plus tax and tip)? If so, you may want to make a reservation at Modo Mio (yes, even on a Tuesday!) and settle in for a long, delicious Italian meal that'll make your belly pop and your heart sing.

I have had Modo Mio book marked for years, literally YEARS, and after my dining experience on Tuesday, I regret that I waited so long to visit.

Zack and I were celebrating Tuesdays, or one month of marriage, or "What do we do now that we don't have to close on a house or plan a wedding?" so we decided to go big with the tasting menu. 

The bread, ricotta, and truffled olive oil were DIVINE to start. The bread comes from a massive crusty loaf, and is just chewy enough. For apps I got the mussels in spicy red (broth so good the server brought me a spoon), and Zack got the cured beef with arugula salad. Very good.

Pastas were lasagna (heaven) and tiny pea raviolis in brown butter. Like day and night, and I felt lucky to go halvsies on both! Entrees were eggplant with ricotta in a chunky tomato sauce, and Zack got the fish of the day ($5) up charge. I only wish there were more options for main courses. Dessert was simple- flour less chocolate cake (like the fudgiest brownie you've ever had) and a basil panacotta (very unique).


Things to note: The portions are not huge, but trust me, you will be rolling out of there after four courses. If you are anti-salt, don't come here. The food wasn't over-salted, but you could DEFINITELY taste it. If you're short on time, don't come here. We arrived at 7pm on a Tuesday and didn't leave until after 9. Make a reservation. They were able to squeeze us in as walk-ins, but the place was packed. 

If you want a romantic, authentic meal- go.

My only resolution for 2013 is to learn something non-scholastic this year. And, considering my proximity to a veritable cheese mecca, it almost seems silly for it not to be cheese.  So, don't be surprised to see me haunting the fromage counter quite often this year.  

Luckily, the mongers of cheese at DiBruno are not only Pros as far as their cheese knowledge and expertise in suggested pairings, they're also some of the nicest folks out there. Not sure what a cheese is? Ask them, they'll explain (and give you a taste). Trying to compare two different styles for that dreamy cheese plate you're concocting? Let em know, they'll join you in taste testing both.  Just a little peckish before lunch? Grab a taste. Seriously, you don't even need an excuse.  It's wins all-around.  And, the thing is, even if DiBruno was limited only to the cheese counter, I'd be happy as a clam.

Luckily (for all of us), there is so much more. Assorted meats for slicing and charcuterie, prepared EVERYTHING so that you can Picnic in the Park with ease and convenience. Their bakery department is always chock-full of carby goodness, and the desserts.... oh baby. Chocolates to please any palate, sweet cupcakes and cannolis, you could just ogle for days.  But, at some point, do yourself a favor and buy something.

I know, I know, it seems pricey. But, as a great man (a fictional man played by Aziz Ansari) once (several times) said: Treat Yo Self. 

I don't think I could do all of (or even 10% of) my shopping for various foodstuffs at DiBruno (unless I stopped paying rent...) but, as far as a special treat when I'm gunning for gourmet, this is my go-to. And, chances are, if you're strolling around during lunchtime or on the weekends, you'll probably end up getting enough free samples to act as a gratis amuse bouche.  And who's not into that?

I've had Jerry's Bar on my bookmark list for a long time.  It was recommended to me by several friends!  I finally made a trip up to NoLibs over the weekend to hit Jerry's Bar on a Saturday night.  I was pleasantly surprised upon walking in, such a warm inviting atmosphere of a cool gastropub.  The bar seats were all taken, so we were seated at a table near the bar.  There's also an entire patio out back, with tons of outside seating that is enclosed inside a patio with cool lighting and a second bar.  That was impressive!

The food was amazing.  We originally came for drinks, but after seeing the glorious options on the food menu, we quickly changed our minds.  We ordered:
1. Trio of Dips - really good! Fresh feta, pickled cucumbers, hummus, red pepper hummus, olives, beets, and a delicious tzatziki.
2.  French Dip - a HUGE sandwich overflowing with meat and cheese. This was so delicious, especially when dipping in the au jus. 
3.  Gnocchi - with goat cheese and sweet potatoes, this was also amazingly delicious! 
4.  Cream cheese doughnuts for dessert was good, and the chocolate dipping sauce made it even better. 

The drinks were also really good!  We had several vodka cocktails with creative mixers that were specialties on the menu.  We also tried a champagne drink and a gin drink from the menu.  For once, I didn't order beer, since the drink menu seemed more interesting than their current beer selections.  Only reason I didn't give 5 stars is because a combo of a few small, relatively unimportant things:  cocktails were steep at $10 each,  one bathroom stall could cause problems on a busy night, our waiter didn't seem very thrilled to be there, although it didn't seem to bother us too much because he was still quick.  Overall, fantastic bar!  Highly recommended.

You should really go to the original loation in the Italian Market for the true experience. However, this location is HUGE and offers everything you could ever need.

Stop here before a party of holiday to grab cheese, Tupelo honey and Nutella and pretend you are a chef at Amada. 

YOU NEED TO TRY: Prima Donna cheese. I have yet to meet someone who didn't say "Wow. What's the name of this again?" It is a bit nutty. (Austin Powers accent).

Such a lovely staff and polite, discrete table service.

This visit my group chose to do the Mesibah chef's tasting menu: it did not disappoint, adding a divine slow-cooked lamb served with pomegranate and a delightful crunchy-on-the-outside dome of spiced rice.  Comments for the other dishes remain as before: spot on!

Big Gay is for people of all ice cream orientations. They can please those with traditional soft serve preferences or those with fancy soft serve ice cream tendencies. The only people who will probably feel out of place here are the lactose intolerants. You can enjoy vanilla, chocolate, or swirl on a cone OR you can dress it up with all types of combinations. Standing in line, it looks like the salted caramel cone affectionately called "The Salty Pimp" was the crowd favorite. I myself am a real vanilla with chocolate sprinkles kinda gal. There's nothing really GAY about it, but the portions are pretty darn BIG. Love it!

holy cow! this place is amazing! my first time ever in a dibruno bros was a couple days ago. i walk past this place almost everyday but have never stopped in until my coworker wanted to grab lunch here! they have everything here! the seafood looks amazingly beautiful and the breads smell so delicious. they also have a little cafe inside!

i grabbed a prepackaged antipasto salad for lunch. omg! the meat and cheeses were incredible. i'm def gonna have to stop by to peruse and shop their meat and cheese selections when i have more time! the only reason for 4 stars vs 5 is that they are very pricey...so yah.

Met a friend here and made it in time for happy hour with 5 minutes to spare. Immediately ordered $5 wines (house Cabernet and pinot noir) and an $8 Margherita pizza to share. The pizza was one of the best wood fired I've had in a long while. Great atmosphere and Ray behind the bar was a delight. I will be back!

My buddy and I decided to go in here on a whim after walking by the place. The aesthetics was what got my attention and it is a great looking gastro pub. The draft and bottle list is pretty good with craft beers and the usual suspects. The bartender was nice and helpful on beer suggestions, so kudos to that. I decided to order Brined Wings with the plum soy and sambai peanut dipping sauce. The wings were awesome and that dipping sauce had a good kick! It is a bit pricey, but it is cool for a once an while dinner and a cool spot to begin the evening.

Went for HH snagged the last two empty seats at the bar & ordered two glasses of special wine a syrah blend that was delish... ( was told tho it got axed from the wine list) 
we got an order of the grilled asparagus w/ pecorino . Heaven on my palate. It was the perfect thing to go with the margarita pizza and red wines.

This place is def on my ra-dah

(to the tune of "That's What I Like" by Bruno Mars)

Hey, hey, hey 
I like to hang out on 13th Street
Shop and drink, and (duh) eat
All of my pals invited
For dinner, we're excited.

Some pizza for your girl, p-pizza for me.
Made a rez, for all four (one more than just three)

We ordr'in Ricotta for the table
Flavors got me unstable
What a start to dinner,
Makes me feel like a sinner...
GF? They got it if you want it, got got it if you want it.
Said they got it since we wanted it, take my wallet if you want it now.
Jump into the menu 
(Girl I want all of the pies)
Large enough to share
(But tummy can be bigger than eyes)
You deserve it baby, you deserve it all.
Zavino gone give it to you.

Some tasty olives (start light)
Or get a salad (yeah, right!)
Lucky for you, pizza all night, pizza all night.
Open so late, pizza all night (pizza all night)
That Joey's sausage, so tight
Or get Diavolo, burn bright
Lucky for you, pizza all night, pizza all night.
Open so late, pizza all night (pizza all night)
Zavino is a great spot to grab some dinner with buddies and just nosh on excellent quality pizza. On my last visit, 3 gals split two pies (while one enjoyed her own GF pizza), and all four split the ricotta appetizer (with GF bread). First of all - that GF bread at the beginning would NEVER have crossed my mind as anything but FULL of gluten, the sign of a great baker. Next - our pizza. Came out fast, toppings all evenly distributed, piping hot and stayed that way while we noshed our way through it. Service was attentive, wait was a little longer than I expected but we changed our reservation last minute and it's a cozy (read: small) joint inside. If you're down to sit outside in the (heated) outdoor area, you may have less to wait, and it's worth it however long you are waiting!

CATERING REVIEW:

We use DiBruno's for catering at work up to 3-4 times per month and we are never dissapointed. The delivery has always been on time and perfectly executed. They wrap everything really secure for transport, but when unwrapped it is laid out beautifully for our lunches. 

I've had a taste of pretty much everything. Green salads, pasta salads, sandwiches,  cheese/italian meats, bread, and dessert trays. My favorite pasta salads are the Mom's Macaroni and the Pasta Carmella (creamy sriracha dressing!). The green salad dressings like balsamic and roasted vegetable vinaigrette are very good. It should be no shock, but the cookies and cannolis are also fantastic. They are a bit pricy, but you get what you pay for and if you're trying to make a good impression this is a good option.

STORE REVIEW:

I thoroughly enjoy walking around the any of the Di Bruno's store locations and checking out all they have to offer. The wide variety of cheeses and bakery goods are hard to resist. This isn't a place to do all of your shopping, as it would be very expensive. It is perfect place to treat yourself to something different here every so often.

Looking for the ideal date spot in Philadelphia? Look no further.

Ladies night (or gents night) with your buddies? Hustle to Zahav.

Lonely and trying to eat your feelings? OR happily alone and just don't wanna share? You've found your spot.

There is no human I can fathom that won't fall immediately in love with Zahav. No matter the dietary restriction (gluten-, meat-, or dairy-free? YOU'RE GONNA BE JUST FINE!), the picky palate, or the range of appetites (from the hungry hippo to the folks just in it for the booze and mezze plates), Zahav has you covered. And while you COULD just be in it for the incredible wine list or an incredibly refreshing lemonnana cocktail, I'd instead recommend that you show up hungry and open-minded. You will only leave with joy in your heart.

Definitely don't skip the Salatim, an ever-changing selection of salads that have so much variety, flavor, color, and texture diversity that it's a culinary rainbow for all of the senses. Their hummus, no surprise, is killer. But you shouldn't fill up on it (don't worry, they are generous with to-go containers) because the courses only improve from there. I've gone for restaurant week (which you can recreate with their Tayim option for $42 any day of the year) and, most recently, to taste their Mesibah option of the roasted lamb shoulder. 

There has not been a bite of food I haven't raved about to friends, strangers, servers, and the internet. Standouts to me include: crispy haloumi (DON'T YOU EVEN THINK OF SKIPPING, REGARDLESS OF DIETARY RESTRICTIONS! That's what Lactaid is for), fried cauliflower, brussels sprouts... 

The grilled options are all well-portioned and cooked in such a fashion that whichever you choose, you'll be satisfied. I fell pretty hard for the lamb merguez... that said, if you can round up some buddies for the Mesibah lamb shoulder, don't hesitate to call ahead and tell them you're interested. It's one of the most perfect meats I've ever consumed, and the leftovers have served me well for three meals after. I honestly almost forget the desserts I've tried because my mind was swirling so quickly after dinner.... But, ya know, they've done no wrong for me to-date, so just ask for a recommendation and eat the heck out of it.

I will jump at any (or no) excuse to come here. Five mouthwatering stars.

Every once in awhile, a meal comes along that is worth its weight in gold. As if I was a 12 year old having the best time of his life at camp, I want to write to mom about this amazing meal.

I've been in Philly for three years now. Often when eating, I reflect on my years in New York City and come out disappointed, because it's such a hard standard. Finally, I found an Italian restaurant that lives up to the quality I know and love.

We went on a Sunday which is Sugo, a family style meal that requires no ordering. Everyone gets the same thing. I knew I was in a real deal spot when I was told the salad came last.

We started off with some antipasti and bread. It was a good mix of olives, meats, cheeses, and vegetables. All very fresh and very tasty.

Then, came the pasta, aka the first wow moment. We got spaghetti, rigatoni, gnocchi, and lasagna. All were fantastic. Their red sauce is superb. The lasagna and gnocchi were truly special. All were cooked to perfection and practically melted in my mouth.

Next, came the meats, the moment my tummy started doing the happy dance. There were the huge meatballs. They were so perfect. So good. There were the sausages. Love! There was lemon rosemary chicken, where the chicken slid right off the bones and tasted glorious. There was some tasty pork as well.

By now I was busting out of my pants. We nixed the salad. There seemed to be no point. Desert was happening, and is part of the deal. They brought out four different deserts for us to share. This was my OMG moment. There was a chocolate cake, a cheesecake, and a couple of other cakes, which I am drawing blank on at the moment - I mean I was almost in a food coma at this point. This was all so so good.

The price was very reasonable and they did not charge for my 3 year old. I seriously love this place. I want to rent a room and eat all my meals at Modo Mio!

Israeli cuisine. Not something that you see that often.  Worth it simply for that.  

Soooooo much food.  I was stuffed long before the meal was over.  We ordered the Tayim (a tasting menu).  I am not sure that I would get the tasting menu again, only because we left so much food uneaten (I would have loved to have taken food home, but we had a long night of  being out afterwards without storage).

SALADS AND HUMMUS:
The selection of salads were terrific, very tasty.  I liked the beet salad and the eggplant ones best.  The hummus was well made.  The salads, hummus, and pita would make a good meal in their own right if you got a bit more pita.  For the amount of salads and hummus you get, there needs to be either more pita or less other stuff.

We were sent out a complimentary dish of smoked salmon and some pickled vegetables.  The pickling on this was too strong for my taste, I did enjoy the smoked salmon though.  It seemed like every table was given a complimentary dish.

SMALL PLATES:
The haloumi and dates might have been my favorite of the small plates, very rich flavor.  
The duck hearts were not too tough, were well seasoned and paired well with what was on the plate.  
The asparagus was cooked well, well seasoned and flavorful.
The last of the small plates was sort of a breaded chicken ball.  It had what might have been rice or couscous inside with some small vegetables.  This was a little dry.  

GRILLED DISHES:
The branzino was served with tzatziki, lemon, and a crispy skin.  My companion liked the fish more than I did, the citrus taste was a bit much for me.  I thought the lamb was delicious.  The peas worked perfectly with the earthy taste of the meat. 

For dessert, she had the pineapple sorbet, I had a carrot cake with apricot.  We both agreed that mine was the better of the two.  A moist cake with apricot baked into it.  

DINNING ROOM AND SERVICE:
I was surprised how loud it was in here.  Tall ceilings, tables close together.  There was a not-so-dull roar until it got pretty late into the night.  The music was interesting, surprising for what we were doing, but great music.  

The service was impeccable.  However, I am not a big fan of the over the top service in places like this.  I don't need new silverware every minute and a half, and my water glass was refilled even when I didn't drink out of it.  I did like that we arrived early for our reservation and were seated as soon as we walked in, I was not expecting that.  We came for our anniversary, and they gave us a complimentary glass of champagne.  A very nice touch.  

All in all, this place is a hype machine.  It was a very good meal, but there are some things that I would order differently at my next visit.  With two weeks notice, I was only able to reserve a table at 10:30 pm on a weekend (we were seated closer to 10 pm).  While I would not agree that it is the best restaurant in Philadelphia, it is very good, and I will be back, if I can get a table.

With all the hype I had heard, I had been wanting to go to Zahav for quite some time. I tried to get reservations there for Valentine's Day, but a month in advance was not quite enough for such a busy occasion.

My wife planned a surprise dinner for my birthday. I knew we were going, but not where we were going. At some point, Zahav crossed my mind because it was a destination my wife knew I wanted to go to, but had not made it to yet. But, not one to beat up on guessing the outcome of a surprise, I let it go.

Prior to dinner, we planned to see a movie. Originally, I was going to choose the 300 sequel at out local theater. A few days prior, I realized The Grand Budapest Hotel was playing at one of the artsy Ritz theaters, which just happened to be a stone throw away from Zahav.

As we were heading to the theater, that feeling about Zahav entered my sphere once again. I made a joke about Zahav to my wife, who had to use all of her will not to give it away. I played it cool, not allowing my feeling to spoil the surprise.

After the move, when the surprise became real, I mustered up some surprise, but the idea of any sort of shock was gone. But surprises are overrated anyway. My wife chose well, and that's what matters.

To say it was a fantastic meal is an understatement. It was mind numbing good. We did the pre fixe menu which allowed us to really feast at a very reasonable price of $39 per person.

First the homemade pita bread with humus and an array of salad items came. The bread was near perfect. The humus was the best I ever had. The other salad items were all delish.

Then, one at a time, came out the first four small plates. The Yam dish was very yummy. The squash dish as well. Another item seems to be escaping me right now. But the one dish I will never ever, ever, ever, forget, the dish that must have been sent to us by the Gods, is the Fried Cauliflower. I quivered after my first bite of this goodness. I want this to be a part of my last meal. Even better, part of every meal, since I might not know when my last meal is, and, well, who cares. I just want to eat it, eat it some more, and just not stop eating it.

I could lie and continue to over hype the Fried Cauliflower by claiming the rest of the meal was a bit of a fog, because the Fried Cauliflower was that good, but the meal continued to blow my mind.

The last two dishes were the chicken and kofte. Both were fantastic. Really, everything about Zahav was flawless. Great food. Great service. I loved the ambiance. All perfect.

Then, there was desert. Perfect, just might not be good enough. My wife got the apples, ricotta cheese, ice cream dish. It was very tasty. But it was rookie league compared to what I got. The mother of all deserts, the wholly one, the Chocolate Bobka. Oh my. Oh my. Oh my. Amazing doesn't say it. Neither does perfect, as I already stated. Nothing does. You just got to eat it. And, only then, will you know what I know. Trust me. You want to do this. Like, badly.

Best. Birthday. Dinner. Ever.

Each and every thing I consumed at Zahav was fabulous. We were in the new party room, which is beautifully decorated, though not quite complete, which meant that the servers had to come outside, though the back of the restaurant, and into the room. (They expect to have the room connected through the restaurant in the next few weeks.) Overall the service was terrific: friendly and attentive, but not overbearing.

Starting with the drinks:

The mint lemonade was delicious: plenty of fresh mint. Others raved about the Marble Rye (pumpernickel & caraway-infused rye, celery soda) and the Lemonnana (bourbon, muddled mint, fresh lemon, verbena).

On to the food:

The Salatim & Humus was amazing. I have never had better hummus...silkily smooth and flavorful.

The small dish of pickled vegetables was fantastic (and a bit spicy!): the miniature eggplant (which looks like a large cherry) was great, but the pickled celery topped them all.

There was a sashimi-style fish that was served with grapefruit that was super-high quality and tasty.

If vegetables were always served like this, all people would eat their vegetables: Brussels Sprouts Al Ha'esh (with whipped feta) and  Fried Cauliflower (Labaneh with chive, oil, mint and garlic).

The slow-cooked lamb, served with crunchy Persian rice, literally pulled off the bone and was seasoned perfectly.

By the time the braised chicken came out, I was stuffed, but had a small bite: tender and yummy.

For dessert, the Hazelnut & Date Rugelach took the prize; however, the espresso chocolate ice cream that was served alongside a baklava was rich, like gelato.
Love soft serve! Love free sprinkles! Love the fun cone holder (catches drips before they hit your hand and allows you to catch all your toppings!)! Great neighborhood addition.

Finally ate here after a year on the bookmark list!  It doesn't need a review from me since there's already 700+ so I'll keep it short.  After seeing the TV show the Layover with Anthony Bourdain, and this was their feature resturant, I knew I had to eat here.  I made reservations 2 weeks in advance, only way to seat a party of 6 during normal dinner hours.  Use OpenTable for reservations, they are the best.  

We had a great experience.  We all had the tasting menu, $39/person, which comes with Laffa Hummus, 2 Mezze's, 1 entree, 1 dessert.  Everything is tapas style small plates and served to the table to share, but you certainly get alot of food ,we were all so stuffed we couldn't finish the plates.  Best part was the hummus and apps, the main courses were not as stellar.  Desserts were great.  Wine was overpriced.  Service was great, but the entire meal took nearly 3 hrs which was exhausting, and I was ready to leave!

I will come back, but for several different hummus plates and apps.  No more wasting time on the main meals.  Hummus was to DIE FOR, and so were nearly all of the apps.  Also, drink ahead of time, the prices on wine & mixed drinks are too much.  $12/ glass wines, cheapest bottle is $50, mixed drinks $12+.  Beer is fine at $5 ish a bottle.

Bravo chef.  Bravo!

This place is EVERYTHING 

When the rumor milled started churning that Philly would one day get their very own big gay ice cream I was beyond excited.

Everyone knows opening an business in this city is almost as hard as fighting a ppa ticket so when I say they were having a "soft opening " on my way home from to the gym I stopped in and though I didn't have an official invite the young lady working the door graciously allowed me to enter.

It was a chocolate kind of day so I opted for the rocky road sundae in a cup to cut down on the calories ( I know pointless ). The rocky road was the perfect combination of salty sweet with toasted marshmallows and almonds . Though usually not a fan of soft serve this particular treat was nothing like the Dairy Queen ice milk I had as a kid. The texture was just solid enough but lickable. I basically ate the entire cup while on my walk home and did an extra 15 min on the treadmill that hopefully made up for my calorie faux paux afternoon snack.

I came here for New Years Eve dinner and was more than satisfied with the entire experience. We were taken for our reservation on-time, our courses came out quickly, our waitress (Marie) was outstanding (as was the rest of the staff that bussed our table, filled our water, brought our bread, etc.), and the food was spectacular. I really have no complaints about this - except to say that I was glad we were not seated in front of the door because it got stuck open every time someone new came into the restaurant. Not to mention that the price is definitely right here... a four-course meal for two people only cost $113.00. 

Here's a breakdown of what I ate in order from my favorite to my least favorite dish:

1. Spinach and ricotta dumplings with a nutmeg brown butter. This was my favorite dish by far. The dumplings were essentially little gnocchis (the texture and heavyness was the same), but the butter sauce was SO GOOD. Guuuuhhhh I just want another plate of these right now.

2. The mussels in a white wine sauce were my second favorite dish because they were the biggest mussels I've ever eaten in my life. Seriously. 

3. Crispy pork tenderloin with beet and horseradish salad. This was essentially a pork cutlet (breaded) with beets on top. I didn't get much horseradish in this dish, but I liked it and was surprised how nicely the beets paired with the pork (I'm not a beet person).

4. Butternut squash ravioli with pancetta and sage. These were definitely good, but they were sweeter than I was expecting, so it's primarily for that reason that they come in a little lower in my ranking.

5. Veal with a mushroom cream sauce. This was good - it reminded me of a cross between beef stroganoff and veal Marsala. 

6. Italian festival sausage with lentils and a balsamic poached egg. This dish was basically a crispy piece of sausage on a bed of lentils with an egg on top. I don't really like poached eggs or lentils, so that's why this is last (and also why my husband was the one to order this for himself!)

For dessert we got a flourless chocolate cake and something else that I can't remember the name of. It was basically a white cake soaked in sambuca stuffed with ricotta cheese and some chunky bits that I can't decide were dried grapes or walnuts and then covered in a hard shell chocolate ganache. I liked both desserts a lot and was stuffed by the time we left. I would absolutely go back here!

This review is well over due .
Modo mio is pretty much the Italian BYOB that all Italian BYOB should be measured against. Incredible food , friendly service and a sambuca after dinner shot.

My second experience here was for a friends birthday dinner a few weeks back.  Our  table of 7 came ready bearing a variety of vintages including a Barolo that almost brought me to tears.

The amuse bouche was an incredible tuna mousse on toast. I followed that up with the beet salad (nightly special ) pappardelle with chickpeas and mushrooms , swordfish and the rice pudding to round it all out. 

The tourista menu is the the way to go you can try a little bit of everything and share with friends . I opted to have a few bites of my pasta and box the rest up it made a great lunch Monday afternoon .

If you haven't been GO

Interesting drinks on a Saturday afternoon.  We stopped in while meandering around, sat at the bar and got a couple of cocktails before we continued to mosey on.  She got a Dragon Mary which was very well made Bloody Mary.  I think it had extra hot sauce or something, I forget what made it "dragon."  They had a couple of Bloody Marys on the menu there.  I had some variant off of an Irish Coffee.  It was also well made and very good.  

I'd come back for cocktails or to try some breakfast food. It deserves another star.

Heard over dinner "I just fu**ed this food"

Those types of expressions are not so uncommon to hear when one dines at Zahav, if this type of talk scares you skip down a few sentences.

Our party of 6 arrived closely to our 8:15 reservation and were seated at a roomy table big enough to fit at least 3 more people. Our server went over the RW menu ( which is pretty much the regular tasting menu just 4.00 cheaper).

We all decided silently on food options and when it was our turn to order we proudly stated our options ranging from duck hearts to foie gras. We would probably share but no one knew for sure.

The first to arrive were our drinks and hummus alongside a trio of salads. My favorite was the beets. It's very strange how ones palate changes I never thought I would  want to SMD in those beets but it did. The hummus at Zahav is better than any other restaurant hummus I've had so far world wide. I would love to know the secret to this magical spread.

A second round of bread was brought out for our dipping pleasures. Courses came out in a a staggered way which have everyone a chance to dive in and share. My favorites were the grilled haloumi, the bête salad and the mackerel.

As food came out conversations slowed down and we enjoyed all the extras sent out by the kitchen . I was too full to enjoy my entire dessert but I took at least one bite from all the options offered and the French press coffee made this such an enjoyable dining experience . I don't think Zahav should be limited to special occasions or RW, the menu and level of service remains the same no matter when you go. Some biddie I'm friends with keeps hinting at wanting a 30th birthday dinner here I'm sure it can be arranged .

[to the tune of "Jessie's Girl" by Rick Springfield]

Jerry's is my place....
Yeah, you know, it's been a great place to drink
But lately something's changed
And I can only eat outside
Jerry's is my go-to spot, and I really can't deny.

And they've got the best bread in town...
And one bite into those potatoes, and I just know it...
Gonna hold onto this place mornings, or late at night...

Already wish I was at JERRY'S BAR!
Always happy at JERRY'S BAR!
Where can I find a mimosa like that?!

You know, pre-pandemic, I'd only been to Jerry's for drinks and late night - but since then, I've enjoyed their gorgeous outdoor dining several times and enjoyed every single visit more and more. Their bread-basket is one for the ages, and I can't get over their Taylor Pork Roll breakfast sammy. The team is great, super friendly and super safe. One visit, it started raining a bit during brunch and they were quick to help us scootch our chairs around so no one (and no food) got drizzled on. Awesome scene, reasonable prices, and a favorite neighborhood spot for sure!

how adorable.
i desperately wanted to go because it was on the list of philly's top 50 restaurants, and i had heard good things.
it was quite easy getting a reservation on a wednesday night.
you must must get the $32 turista deal...otherwise things are too pricey.
i had the grilled octopus appetizer followed by ravioli...then a ribeye steak with prosciutto, cheese and egg (yes, i am trying to die of a heart attack)...and a creme caramel for dessert.
to die for.  the portions can be fairly large, but so tasty.  the bread is amazing and comes with a lemon-y olive oil.

the only downside?  it's in the middle of nowhere.

Even though I gave them 5 stars, I am having difficulties writing this review. That's because when I Entered this temple of taste, I transformed
into a dream state.
 I walked around in a complete haze walking on clouds, and my nose became my eyes taking me from counter to counter. I tasted cheese after cheese, soft ones, hard ones, spicy ones- all kinds!
 I sampled all types of breads, spreads and crackers. 
Now I'm levitating to the deli counter And slices of salty and spicy meats attack my mouth. I tried olives of all colors, samples of the salads, candied nuts and such.
 When I awoke From this dream standing on Chestnut st with food stains down the front of my shirt holding a bag and $47 dollars poorer!

i'm sorry zahav, i had to take off one star for oddness.

as everyone has said...  food is fantastic.  my favorites?  turkish hummus and the salatim.  get like, 14 orders of these.  the haloumi is awesome.  so is the fried cauliflower.  ok, pretty much everything in the dairy and appetizer column is amazing.  

so why the one star off?  i made the mistake of going to butcher and singer for lunch (who could resist a 5.95 burger?)...so i was pretty darn full.  but my eyes were bigger than my stomach (as it usually tends to happen)...so i got the tasting menu.  and i was so full that i didn't finish my branzino.

and this causes the manager to come up to my table and ask me if there was anything wrong with the food.  now, as sweet as this was, my pseudo-jewish guilt kicked in, and all i wanted to do was to tell her to bring me back my unfinished fish and i would eat it all.

so yes.  eat all your food.
Always a hit post dinner drinks. Two glasses of red for me and three beers for him. That makes a total of 90 different wines that I have tried and 67 beers the boy has tried.

Updating my review from 2012, I was dissappointed there were slim to none veggie options.  Now they have a wonderful huge veggie salad with:  Roasted Celery Root, Fennel Butternut Squash, Lentil Vinaigrette, Baby Arugula.   Its dammmmn good so now I'm a happy camper :-)   That earns Cambridge 4.5 stars now!  (not 5 because its always packed and loud).  Still love this place!  I'm here often.  Everything else about my prior review is still true!  Oh, and the nachos are really yummy too!

Good vibe, if slightly loud for dining conversation (but we were seated right next to the bar, so I think the other side would've been quieter).

Food was solid, particularly the bacon tomato bisque with grilled cheese-like croutons and the fish'n'chips. My House Grind burger was good, though not evenly cooked all the way through, and the fries were yummy. None of the food I tasted/ate was overly salted--perhaps the chef saw the earlier reviewer and adjusted?

Ps. Hawthorne in Your Side (Laphroaig 10 yr Scotch, Drambuie, Fernet Branca, Cinnamon Syrup, Angostura, Orange bitter) is awesome.

The Cambridge continues to be a go-to for pub grub done well. The service is consistently pleasant with a nice (if sometimes noisy) atmosphere. It also serves a mean brunch with an omelette that zings with diced, spicy, pickled jalapenos and well-seasoned potatoes.

Varga Bar will always have a special place in my heart as it is the first place dining partner and I ever dined together. The first time we went we sat outside, both ordered Miss August cocktails that were pink and delightful, and split crab fries and kobe beef sliders. The crab fries weren't just seasoned with old bay, there was actual crab meat on the fries! The sliders were pretty good, but after four drinks any food was appreciated.

We came back for our second go-around Friday evening and managed to get a table outside in a prime people watching location. Hoping to reenact our first dining experience, we both ordered Miss August drinks. There was a curiosity about whether or not last time the drink included whiskey, but we dismissed it because we remembered it being really good. The drinks arrived but they were yellow and less delightful. When we asked the waitress what the deal was, she explained that the drinks change month to month, so the Miss August we previously experienced had changed. This was fine, totally our misunderstanding. There was no offer of a  different drink, weird for customer service, but understandable. Not ones to let alcohol go to waste, we reluctantly suffered through them to get them out of the way and ordered the Pink Lemonades, much more our speed. For food, I ordered the pulled pork tacos and dining partner ordered the lobster roll special. Both were really good, especially his lobster roll. The pulled pork in my tacos was super juicy and drippy-YUM. The tortilla itself was disappointing, lacking flavor. Maybe it needed salt? Who knows. This is a really cool place, with lively people having a good time. The craft beer selection is extensive however I get distracted and end up ordering colorful cocktails. There are more Varga nights ahead.

Dining Partner and I made our first trip to Dim Sum Garden on a Thursday around 6:30pm. We easily scored seats, but right as we were seated, a line began to form. It doesn't appear that the tables are any one server's responsibility as we were helped by several people. Dishes come out as they are ready. We had the scallion pancakes, fried pork dumplings, pork soup dumplings, and shrimp fried riced. There was a lot of food for each dish, two of us split everything, but I tapped out a bit before Dining Partner. All dishes were great and it's hard to pick a favorite.  I can't wait to go back and try more. It's BYO and seems like it would be a fun place with a group of people.

oh my! i'll have one of everything on the menu please...i mean, we almost kind of did. lol dim sum heaven. 

over the labor day weekend, i met up with some friends here. there's always a line to get a table but it moves pretty quickly. 

amongst the three of us, we shared a few things which i can't remember now but included some spicy pork soup, veggie, moon pie, and scallion pancakes. after the first round, we decided we all could eat more so we ended up ordering some crunchy something (but they messed up and gave us spicy pork soup again), some kind of mushroom thing, and some garlic pork noodles? 

if you're thinking how the heck did you finish all of that?! well...i'll tell you...we didn't! lol we almost did though. 

our server was very friendly and efficient. i'll def go back!

There was this one time that every meteorologist in Philadelphia predicted the storm of the century. Her name was Juno, and she was supposed to be a beast. And so we watched, and we waited, and we bought an outrageous amount of milk, bread, and eggs (as is tradition). The weather outside was frightful. But not REALLY that frightful. So I made my way to the gym, like a winner. After destroying it, I felt like I truly belonged at the top of the food chain.

Enter: Percy Street Barbecue. Namely, their Meat Week. For $20, the Meathearts (like sweethearts, but meatier) at Percy Street offered family style Brisket (MOO), Chicken (cluck), and pulled pork (OINK!), pinto beans with brisket burnt ends, german potato salad with a warm bacon vinaigrette, collard greens with smoked ham hocks, coleslaw, extra sharp cheddar mac & cheese, and buttermilk chive skillet cornbread.

Yup. A little bite of every beast you could want, savory sides, Texas toast. The hits seemingly kept coming, and by the end of the meal, the five of us were left with bellies teeming with protein (proteeming?) AND leftovers. All for $20 per person! Can't be beat. Sure, that was just for one (12 day) week BUT Percy Street's Lockhart (same deal minus the cornbread and mac& cheese) can be purchased ANY DAY OF THE YEAR! Sure, you miss out on mac & cheese and cornbread, but pretend you're going low-carb and you'll never miss them.

(You might miss the mac & cheese, but for $6 it could [and should] be yours.)

They've been doing all you can eat ribs on Wednesdays lately, so just check out potential specials before you head out. You never know what kinda meaty goodies you could get your hands (and mouth) on at Percy Street!

I was excited when the Poi Dog cart opened. Its a tiny, roaming cart, bringing big Hawiaan plates to Philly.

 
Tacos and smaller wrapped snacked are available, but for the most serious lunch option, the 2 meat plate lunch option is it. I picked the pork and the chicken. Plate lunches come with rice (white or brown) and a macaroni salad that is kind of negligible, which according to my Hawaiian, is very authentic.

The kalua pork, with its bits of cabbage, was smokey as promised, and shredded nicely without being overcooked and mushy. It could have used a little more salt, spice, or acid.
But this haole really enjoyed the fried chicken. Small pieces were breaded, karage style, except with seaweed in the batter. It was crispy and unexpected and the chicken inside was tender.
The two portions of meat along with the 2 scoops of rice that come with the plate will surely give you enough energy for a powerful haka session.
 
For dessert, I enjoyed a pair of coconut mochi, just barely sweet and pleasantly squishy.

Can't believe I haven't written a review yet for as often as I come here.  About time!
I love Varga Bar because:
First and foremost:  Buck a shuck Oysters!! All day every day!!! (except now i'm told they are no longer $1 on Fri & Sat, which is OK by me, too busy anyway).  I'm used to most gastropubs serving $1 oysters only during 5-7pm HH.  Not Varga!! Come here at 10pm, who cares!? Still get your oysters for a dollar.  
Secondly, the food is always top notch.  Everything I've had has been phenomenal.  Turkey & warm brie sandwich with caramelized apples was lip smacking delicious.  The pork tacos were also great.  The Boston Bib Lettuce wraps were so yummy, and so was the veggie burger.  I've heard (but not tried yet), the truffle mac & cheese is a signature dish along with the brussel sprouts, so I will try those next. 

The place itself is small, but there's plenty of outside seating which is nice.  They open up the huge windows to the outside seating area.  Waitresses are always friendly.  The bartenders are nice, and very knowledgeable about the beer.

There is about 20 taps here, always rotating and they always have several selections of "heavy hitters" with 10%+ ABV.  You will always find something rare here.  Also, if you're not a beer drinker (sorry for you!), J/K, they also have several kinds of specialty house mixed drinks that are delicious.

Varga bar is certainly one of my favorite local spots in the city, to drink a rare craft beer, eat some dollar oysters, and chow down on amazing food.  Hell, I love this place so much that I bought the t-shirt!

"I like this place" I said to myself as i walked in the dark bar with candles flickering all around me. Our table of 6 was seated and orders were placed for various beverages. I tried my hand at the Fig Side Car. I never knew i liked side cars until the sweet nectar of cognac passed my lips last night. The Cambridge's version comes up with fig and cinnamon infused cognac and squeeze of lemon and the twist of an orange peel. Total. Utter. Perfection. The gents seemed impressed with the beer list ( for the most part) and the have glasses of Bele Casel prosecco. One downside to me was the price point on some of the wines namely the 10 a glass for Sophia Coppola bubbles ( interesting is the only word that comes to mind) some of the other options were out of reach to me even for us being on this side of Broad. I would return again. Our groups conversations will make everyone run for cover. Ill reiterate I like it here this time i said it out loud , loudly,
Oh yes there was mention of the infamous #PFBD action ( yes i hashtagged , and yes it was necessary)

You can't miss with this place. If you are planning on chatting with friends or being in love with your date (or just loving tapas), then opt for a bottle, as glasses of wine are about $8.

Every dish here is amazing. Get a few snacks (aka: appetizers) and fewer sandwiches (panini's). Desserts are not a questions - do not skip these!

Here are my choices:

Warm Poached Black Mission Figs with Gorgonzola and Prosciutto di Parma snack
Brie with Allagash-Poached Cherries brushetta
moked Chicken with Apple Mustard, Sliced Apple, Brie and Arugula Grilled Panino
Banana, Caramel and Mascarpone Panino

I never knew they had a patio out back here.  It's very nice.  Lights strung overhead, it seems like a quieter place back there.  The patio also closes earlier than the bar, which is a shame.  I would have spent the rest of the night back there.  

By my count, this is a beer bar.  I have found a couple of interesting brews here, and some things that I haven't previously tried.  I was impressed with the Horchata Ale by Cigar City Brewing that I tried in my most recent visit.  It was a cream ale, very drinkable, and you can taste all of the flavor that you would expect from horchata in the finish.  

Staff was friendly and fast.  We weren't waiting long for a round.

I've always loved the original Dim Sum Garden, which is a total hole in the wall dive tiny Chinese place with the best dumplings you'll ever eat in your life.  So now I'm ecstatic that I've finally visited their new location, which is trendy, bigger, cute decor, and much more comfortable. Luckily, the amazing quality of food is still the same!!  Must eat literally all the dumplings on the menu. There's a whole page of them, so just order the dumplings and skip the grand meals! The soup dumplings are by far the signature item, both the pork and the crab dumplings are the best. Served over a steam pot dish, you pinch the dumplings in the side to let the hot soup drain out in our spoon and slurp it up. Then continue to eat the rest of the dumpling whole. Don't eat before pinching out the juice unless you want to burn your mouth!  The fried chicken dumplings were also yummy, fried rice is great, the shai Mia dumplings are also delicious!! Highly recommended as my favorite spot in china town.

Having never been to Varga before Philly Beer Week 2013, I decided that I would really make a splash and go four times in the six nights I went out. This worked out so well that, when presented an opportunity to complete a participant observation exercise for a grad school class, I opted to observe the Varga patrons and staff instead of the local coffee shop. Here is what I turned in to my professor (I got an A).

I visited Varga Bar at 5:30pm-6:20pm Thursday, June 6th, 2013. It was overcast with a few drizzles outside, but not enough to prevent folks from dining al fresco. The outside looks clean and is maintained nicely (impressive considering the white brick). I imagine that some folks are drawn in simply because of the appearance. The open-window style is very appealing, and the fact that people were sitting outside despite the slight drizzles shows that it's clearly a hot spot to be.

Varga Bar seems to be a "cool" spot for families, young professionals, local beer aficionados, and everyone in between. They have a great deal during happy hour, and the space is comfortable and kitschy with the whole pinup theme. The staff definitely seems to have a solid relationship with each other, giving a friendly vibe to the establishment before you even interact with anyone.  The crawfish boil experience, while not novel or new to me (since I've been living in the South for a while), seemed to draw in a number of people wanting to try something new, and I saw faces both light up and look very confused when the crocks were brought to their table. Philly Beer Week can bring people to new locations that they might not usually visit otherwise and that may also have been breathing some new life into the happy hour period of time. It was a comfortable scene, and one that I plan on recreating soon (though hopefully without the notepad and pen).

The inside was very comfortable though, at times, a tight squeeze for the employees to get past the patrons (always at the expense of the employees comfort/time, though, never an issue for the patrons). There were paintings of pinup girls on the ceiling and a few posters on the walls, and it had a very put-together feel, the whole restaurant/bar going along with the theme. The kitchen's location was unobtrusive to all but maybe the very last booth in the back, and even then only when the servers were bringing things back. The lighting was definitely more "bar" like than simply restaurant, without being dingy but definitely a little dimmer than I'd expect from a mere restaurant.

The employees all seemed to fit into the at-times-cramped space and move like a well-oiled machine. There were no arguments that I overheard, and no complaints from the customers regarding timing or service. I think that this was not a normal night at Varga due to the crawfish boil taking place. However, I noticed with the friendly atmosphere and comfort that many patrons seemed to have that it felt like "business as usual". As it was Philly Beer Week, it's likely that there were more people there for beer than food, though a number of folks seemed drawn in by the novelty of the crawfish. Stopping by around happy hour, I was bound to come across all different types of people from post-work relaxers to families to buddies just grabbing a drink and starting the weekend off early. I thought it was funny that the one person I observed eating a meal from start to finish took a photo of his food, because I definitely caught a number of other people doing the same thing.

5/429.

That's how many Yelp reviews for Percy Street BBQ mention the burger. That's it. FIVE. Out of FOUR HUNDRED AND TWENTY-NINE.

I consulted with Vinny P. and Rebecca S. before ordering this hush-hush burger, and I'm sure glad I did. The Percy burger might be one of the best burgers I've had the pleasure of eating in Philadelphia. Talk about underrated! 

It's like the best homemade burger you've ever made on your grill, times a thousand. Soft, perfectly cooked-to-medium ground brisket, a slice of cheddar, a compact bun that fit in my palm and didn't break once, pickles and onions. No puddle of grease or pit in my stomach at the end. Just $11 (yeah, it's kind of a lot for a burger with no sides) of pure beef bliss. 

Fun fact: on your birthday you get to spin the wheel by the jukebox, and maybe win a coozy or a beer or a slice of pecan pie.  Pecan pie FTW. If you don't like pecan pie (you're crazy), the key lime is to die for. Really. 

Other great stuff: BBQ chicken, the "Lockhart" in general, the pork belly sandwich (Zack's fave). The macaroni and cheese.

Pass on: the apple citrus salad. Pretty small and with weird flavors. Too much pepper and olive oil for a sweet salad. We ate it all but told the truth to our server when he asked about it- he ended up taking it off our bill. Did I mention the service is friendly, fast and wonderful? Man, I love this place.

MEAT: The pulled pork was delicious, it didn't need any barbecue sauce and paired well with the slaw.  The pork had a deep meaty-fatty flavor and was juicy.  There wasn't as much of a taste of smoke, but was very good.  

The Smoked pork tenderloin was falling apart on the plate and paired with the mustard tasting vinaigrette perfectly.  While it isn't what I would consider a traditional barbecue dish (it's a little fancy for all of that), it has my praise. This dish definitely gave the pulled pork a run for it's money. 

SIDES: portions could have been larger, not enough in a serving to share between a table.

The cole slaw worked perfectly with the pork, it was drier (which I like) and a sweet slaw.  I would order this by the pound to take home. 

The German potato salad was good, not the best I've had, but pretty damn good. Potatoes were soft, taste had some tang to it.

The collard greens were alright.  They were soft, but did not have as much of a meaty flavor as I'd have liked.  They lacked sweetness, spice, or smoke.  Fairly bland.  Not terrible, but lacking from what I'd hope for.

SAUCE:  The three types available are hot, mild and sweet.  The hot was my favorite.  It was a slow burn that sneaks up on you.  It wasn't incredibly hot, so I think most wouldn't need to be wary of it.  The hot had a good flavor to it as well.  

DRINKS: Pretty good list of beer and spirits, especially bourbon and rye (as it should be).  Nothing incredibly rare, but a pretty good list. 

I'd like to come back to go through their menu a bit more.  Interested in seeing how the ribs compare to others in the area.

Stopped in for a quick dinner and found a nice shop with pleasant staff. Was pleased to note the local traffic for dinner--eat-in and take-out.

Very tasty Lomi Lomi Salmon (refreshing and everything's chopped to about the same size so the flavors really meld well). The Kalua Pig and Cabbage plate was a good size and flavorful (slightly salty, as others have reviewed) and the macaroni was adequate (nothing special, but I didn't eat it while in Hawaii, so I've nothing to compare it to). The saimin soup was good, but it didn't use traditional saimin noodles.

I don't know what I was thinking when I went in here, because I HATE BBQ. I honestly thought "I'm so hungry, this place has always looked cool, I'm sure I can just get a burger." Then I was seated looking at a menu and felt like it was too late to back out.

The good news is that everyone was super friendly and the entree, BBQ chicken, was pretty damn tasty. Sadly my sides were dramatically bland, especially the German potato salad which tasted more like cold potato flavorless lumps.

It gets four stars for atmosphere, decor, friendly staff and a surprisingly good chicken BBQ. I've never been back because, again, as a general rule I don't like BBQ. But if YOU do, you should check it out!

Food is Amazing here.  I'm only giving it 4 stars because the prices are high for the small portion sizes, but that's what you expect when you're eating at RIttenhouse square.

Many many choices of cheese!  
Bruschetta - The Mozzerella Crema w/ Basil Pesto Bruschetta was fantastic.  
Snacks - The Truffled Egg toast & Smoked Salmon were both good too, both came on really thick toast with Cheese spread on it, almost like a think texas toast without the garlic.  Was very good.  
Salads - The salads were also very good, the salmon salad w/ spinach, Fregola Sarda, and Fennel Lentil was really good.  The cream dressing is very light and the toppings were tastey.  If you want a sweeter salad, go for the Mission Fig & Gorgonzola Dolce salad - that was awesome, the figs were sweet and freshm and the dressing was more of a sweet balsamic.

Overall, very very tasty food.  Overpriced for portion sizes, but its OK, you're also paying for the up-scale atmosphere and unique menu choices.  Definatly reccommend going here for wine & munchies, but not a full meal.

A little pricey, but great BBQ every time I go. Love the mac and cheese, jalapeno cornbread, and loaded fries. The cobb salad with brisket is a good portion-size and had a truly awesome avocado on it--yum-my!

The soup dumplings ( AKA the juicy pork dumplings) are amazing.  Hot pork soup inside the dumpling.  My personal favorite are the steamed variety.  Be careful eating them, that you don't burn yourself.  My favorite thing to do is wait until they are just cool enough and pop the whole thing into my mouth (with a little spicy oil).  When you bite it that way, its like a giant savory Gusher.  

The Chinese broccoli is my favorite vegetable served here.  It is absolutely PACKED with garlic.  The bok choy is also terrific.

Great dim sum, the napa and pork dumplings are also really good, pretty good noodles.  Also, try the the duck fried rice.  

The frantic speed that food used to come out at the original location has slowed down a bit, but service isn't really slow. It looks much fancier than the original location, and it's much easier to get a seat at. 

Cash only.

LOVE this place, what a marvelous addition to the 15th & south neighborhood.   I have been here several times, mostly for drinks.  They are definitely a BEER bar, with 15-20 beers on tap at once.  Several are rare, hard to find craft beers (look for the  *stars on the menu for the rare ones).  They are always changing out the kegs, so when a keg kicks, a new beer, of similar style, replaces it.  You can see on the menu which beer is coming up next. 

The atmosphere is rustic inside, similar to the Farmers Cabinet, but not as "up scale."  The outside patio is large and cozy.  The inside rustic appeal is original, wooden booths, bar stools, and tables.  Neat!   

The best part of this bar is actually sitting at the bar.... the bartenders can tell you all about the beer menu, make recommendations, and teach you about the different beers.   I have NOT had a waitress with the beer knowledge that I'm looking for, so always get a sub-par experience from the waitresses.  Now I always sit at the bar for the best experience, because the bartenders rock.

OK, now the food - its great!  Simple menu, but everything is very tastey. 
The OCTOPUS  was really good!  Had a charred grill flavor to it.  
The BLACK BEAN BURGER was delicious!  I loved it, ate every last bite. 
My only suggestion is I wish there were more vegetarian options -- a bigger salad (all they have is spring mix lettuce, no toppings), or a side vegetable would have been great.

Overall, fabulous place for craft beers, good atmosphere, and tastey food.  I come here often, and will continue!

Officially my favorite spot in Chinatown. I've tried many, many Chinatown joints and they're always just "fine." Mildly disappointing, nothing special.

Dim Sum Garden, however, has awesome food at awesome prices. On one occasion, I was with a party of 9 and the bill was $90. Another time we had a party of 12 and we had to throw down $19 each after legitimate feast. 

The soup dumplings, shrimp dumplings, and scallion pancake are fantastic to start with. 

Lots of great veggie options here, too- hand drawn noodles, eggplant with garlic sauce and the classic Buddha's delight aim to please. Veggie fried rice is fresh tasting- not too much grease here. 

They take reservations. BYOB.

Skip the entrees. The best things here are the apps and salads. Get the Burmese tofu (made from chickpea), the green tea leaf salad, and the thousand layer pancake. 

Not BYO.

OK, so this is my 3rd review of Cambridge, I keep updating it to more and more stars! I'm finally giving the 5th star because: 

- They change the menu often enough to keep adding more veggie options, and rotate the main courses or sandwich options
- Brunch is just as good as dinner, if not better. I've finally been here several times for brunch, and always have a great, meal. My friends love the brunch here too. Beer & Breakfast? Perfect combo.
-  They are one of the top craft beer bars in Philly, still.  The beer list will ALWAYS have some rare selections (look for the stars on the menu, or the pours that are only 6 oz glass!). I love this. I literally chose my beer based upon the size, I scan down the list and any beer that is only 6oz, thats the one I want! Because it is the best beer!  

I come to Cambridge all the time. Its one of my go-to bars.  Hence, here's the 5th star. 

Tip: My 5 stars is only for bar area service. Directly at the bar, or the high-top tables against the back bar. I always find service to be better in the bar than in the restaurant.

Sunday School Magic :) 
Sundays cheese was one of my fav's from the SS menu in a while. they usually don't put the cheeses from SS on the menu but i said a small prayer maybe the cheese Gods are listening...

What happens when you get a table full of Yelpers a few sheets to the wind .someone mentions a food places and its .. Munchies at Varga Bar that's what.

We descended on this place like a pack of hyenas in need of nourishment. A few of us split the sprouts, crab fries, lettuce wraps, wings and sliders. I loved the Mac and cheese it was creamy, cheesy and everything you'd expect from this comfort food staple. 
The sprouts were unexpectedly delish, they were so good usually im not a huge fan of sprouts but these were roasted with balsamic vinegar, crispy leaves, parmesan, olive oil.
The crabfries deserve all the attention and mention they receive. They didnt skimp on the cheese, crab or truffle oil that's poured on top of the golden brown, perfectly good potatoes. I had to drive home so opted out of another bevy but managed to steal a sip of the Miss November it was quite good... 
I need to come back here ASAP our server was friendly and even moved us to an outdoor table big enough to fit our crazy asses

(to the tune of Ariana Grande's "7 Rings")

Yeah, they've got musubi - that Spam, I want double,
Adobo fried chicken will get me in trouble,
Kalua pig, well, I can't get enough,
Poi Dog is serving some of the best stuff.

Prices might seem steep, until you take a bite
Who gets the last andagi? May cause a fight...
The Loco Moco, it's basically BRUNCH,
Poi Dog Snack Shop is the best of the bunch.

That Poi Dog, I'm lovin', my tummy - it's rumblin'
that poke - it's spicy, each bite - so nicey.
You like the dish?
Well duh, they made it.
From scratch, they're cooking
I can't... stop eating.

Before you order, let me warn you: this is not "Hawaiian Chipotle". This is homemade Hawaiian cooking, served in a fairly quick, casual setting.  But it's also high quality ingredients, several straight from Hawaii, and most sourced sustainably. 

The poke isn't going to be topped with guac, mango, sesame seeds, or everything but the kitchen sink - it's traditional, served with warm, sticky rice and it's DELISH.  The Shoyu Ahi (with tuna, macadamia, shoyu, sesame, sweet onion) is unlike anything I've ever tried, and has a nice ginger zing. Two thumbs way up! The Loco Moco is a true feast - unless you're ravenous, you could easily share between two mouths. And if the Adobo fried chicken is on the menu, you're a fool not to get it.

Sweet tooth? I'm not wild about the butter mochi, but I can't say this loudly enough "Get the Andagi!" - they're like little mini funnel cake balls, only crispier. NOT to be missed. It's not going to be as cheap as grabbing a hoagie down the street, but it's going to fill you with way more interesting and satisfying flavors, ingredients, etc.

Surprised it's been so long since I've been, as I remember its offerings fondly. The Cambridge didn't disappoint on this second impromptu trip. The short rib mac'n'cheese is cheesy and delicious (love the bread-crumb topping!) and the nachos are super-crispy, well-seasoned, and pretty evenly distributed topping-wise!

As a specific update re: volume, seated on the other side of the restaurant (away from the bar) was quieter and completely conducive to conversation. The wait for outdoor seating was almost 30 minutes, so we opted for the quicker service. There was some cigarette smoker(s) lingering near the open windows, which was a bit unpleasant.

Let's start with what everyone talks about:
The Jungle Pork was very good, even if it is a little bit of a strange flavor.  The sauce tastes like a lime/cream sauce (which I would think would curdle, but doesn't happen at all).  I don't really know how else to describe it, but people are right.  It's very good.

The same can be said about the Thousand Layer Bread.  Excellent, soft, flaky pancake with potato curry sauce.   Very similar (if not exactly the same) as roti canai.  The sauce had just the right amount of heat.

The Banana Leaf Fish was crispy fish with a nicely spiced sauce served with vegetables.  The sauce paired with the crispy fish worked perfectly.  

I tried the plum wine, it was too sweet for my taste.

Wow-eeee. This place is GOOD!

The folks at my office got a large take-out order to celebrate our co-worker's birthday. We got a wide range of things - from soups, to salads, to appetizers, to entrees. Everyone loved everything they got! I didn't hear one complaint from anyone.

Their thousand layer bread with potato dipping sauce is to die for. It's so spicy and delicious, I just couldn't believe how yummy it was. Definitely don't skip it!

The crab rangoons were amazing. I thought "oh, these will be good" but then when I bit into the filling I realized that they were really, really, really, REALLY good. I didn't even need any of the dipping sauce that came with them.

I was sad that their online menu didn't have the Northern Burmese Noodles as an option to order - because that's what I really wanted - but I got the rice stick noodles instead. They were spicy and delicious, so it all worked out.

I'm down with Rangoon. I'll definitely return.

anybody who knows me would know that i'm a sucker for varga girls and all things pinup...  so i was so excited when i heard about this place.  

i headed there on a late sunday afternoon.  outdoor seating a-plenty, on a semi-quiet street (so not sucking down exhuast fumes!).  they've got a good beer and wine selection at reasonable prices.  and they have pickled vegetables.  what else can beat that?  the rest of the gastro-pub menu ain't half bad, either.
the server was v. sweet.  not the most knowledgeable or best at remembering what we ordered, but always came back to double check...she gets an A for effort. 
crowd consists of the neighborhood-y types.  perfect.

yes my dear pinups, i shall be back!

I lived in Hawaii a long time and the Aloha Spirit will never leave my soul.  I have been eating at a Poi Dog's food truck for years chasing them all around the city based on info posted on Facebook.  I went there for the "ono grinds" and to talk story about Hawaii. 
Nowadays I don't have to chase them down,  I just go to their little snack shop in center city.  
I enjoy the Hawaiian favorites like Kailua Pig and cabbage,  Loco Moco , Lomi Lomi Salmon,  Po'ke, spicy Ahi,  Spam Musubi and much more ono foods that "went broke the mouf"
Hawaiian cuisine is diverse,  so inclusive of the world,  it hard not to fall in love with.  Add a little Hawaiian music and some tropical flowers and a little pakalolo,  I'm transformed into Konaboy again,  jumping off that big ass rock in Waimea Bay.

Sunday School at Tria has become my ritual.  Nothing beats half off wine, cheese, and beer.  It's so decadent without the price.
Salads are excellent, and I'm a huge fan of the brie and strawberry bruschetta.  The staff is friendly and knowledgeable and hipster cool.  It's my Sunday night love.

Love the new location! This 1020 Race Street location has a cleaner, fresher atmosphere than the original location (59 North 11th Street), though after walking by the original location, it looks like it has had a rejuvenating face lift.

The food: Scallion Pancake (so good that we ordered another!); Shanghai Crabmeat & Pork Soup Dumplings; Pan Fried Beef Dumplings; Chives & Pork Dumplings; Sauteed Shanghai Bok Choy (I adore bok choy!!! Again, so good that we ordered another!); sauteed spinach; and their renown Ma Po Tofu with Minced Pork (which was spicy enough to satisfy the spiciest mouth at the table)!

All the dumplings were fabulous, though I think I preferred the Chives & Pork Dumplings. It's a must to try the soup dumplings for the experience, but I think I like the flavor of non-soup dumplings better (and they're certainly less work to eat!).

The service: Attentive without hovering. We were immediately able to flag down a server to place an additional order, and it didn't seem to matter who we flagged down.

In sum: Great food for reasonable prices = we will definitely return!

I really like the food here. They have great flavor and fresh ingredients. The issue is always been the service that is not always great. Some of people working here don't want to be here and are not trained with the best customer service skills.  Also the kitchen staff sometimes just don't want to be bother with making certain things i.e. their poke that you can buy by the pound to take home. It sucks because Poi Dog used to be just a food truck and you get consistency with the food and service Now with a store front, things change a bit. Luckily, the owner knows business and is passionate about sharing food from her childhood memories. I do agree that the portion can be small for the high price that not everyone likes. For me, they have the best tasting tofu poke that I like compared to others in the city. Their tofu helps me with clean eating. Also they have really good desserts that is worth trying.

I went to Percy st. BBQ with friends and family the other night and we had a wonderful time. Our server was so sweet and efficient and pretty too.
I ordered the Brisket served half & half (fatty/lean) and it melted in my mouth. The accompany sauces were pretty tasty as well. I had the pinto beans and the mac-n-cheese along with the midget skillet of cornbread. Everything I ordered was delicious.
Everyone else ordered the all you can eat baby back ribs. I tried one and it was a tad too tough for my taste, but everyone else thought they were fine. Our server bent the rules a little and let us take home an entire rack of leftover ribs and some sauce too.
Overall, it was really enjoyable but a tad too expensive for BBQ. The banana pudding was great.

The food is great here and I love the Faluda dessert. I always get the thousand layer bread. The explosive tofu is good as well. Rangoon has a great tastes and is good for vegetarians. If you come here and know what to order and you should be good.

Rangoon is supposed to be an Burmese restaurant, well I've never been to Burma before but I think their menu is more fusion than not. 
Rangoon is a nice, clean, comfy spot run by family. I was here once before about 10 years ago and the mother who runs the restaurant asked me where have I been when I ate there recently. I thought she was taking a stab in the dark but she asked about the young lady I was with and said 'have a seat Bruce'. Go figure! 
I sat down and I remembered something I had to have.... The Thousand Layer Bread! Rangoon has the best version of that Andalusian Bread that's crispy on the outside and gooey on the inside with a lot of flaky crust. It is amazing. 
I ordered a appetizer called Vatana which is a curry stew with potatoes and chicken and a plate of-you guessed it, Thousand Layer Bread. I wolfed that dish down and immediately ordered another of the same. I know, I know 2 of the same appetizers ain't cool but it was so damn good. 
Next I ordered the Jungle Chicken which was Chicken breast stir fryed with a ton of fresh, crisp veggies, served with steamed rice. It was delicious and filling. 
The menu at Rangoon is humongous, reminiscent of those large menu's at the old school Chinese restaurants back in the day. I'm sure anyone with an appetite and a few bucks can find something to tickle their fancy here.

i've been here a couple of times (it's such a trek to chinatown, especially in the winter!)...and it's quite tasty.  the thousand layer bread...i could just eat orders and orders of that.
the main courses are tasty...i'd go with the night market noodles.

Doma has the biggest shrimp shumai you'll ever eat. Delicate flavors ever so carefully dipped in spicy Chinese mustard that'll clear out your sinuses before you can swallow. 

I went to Doma with a party of six on my 25th birthday. We had four sushi eaters, one vegetarian, and one chick who has tried so hard so many times, but just doesn't like sushi (love ya, Rebecca L!). 

The sushi eaters gorged on fresh simple and fancy rolls. The vegetarian had a veggie bibimbap and a massive bowl of garlic edemame. The non-sushi eater had the salmon entree. Everyone was happy. And when everyone's happy on your birthday, it makes it extra happy, no?

Fried banana and red bean ice cream came out with a candle on it. The entire meal was classic upscale Japanese/Korean fare that was very much enjoyable- but... Umai Umai is better.

As always, was so happy to have a reservation (saw the list and wait times for the walk-ins crowded by the door).

The chef's "gift" to the table of sheep's milk ricotta was awesome: creamy and tangy, thanks to the balsamic! Two other appetizers we greatly enjoyed: the roasted beet salad and the bruschetta, which I believe was a late-addition to the Restaurant Week menu (though I do wish the cherry tomatoes had been sliced and distributed as they tended to roll off the balsamic drizzled bread).
