The capricciosa pizza was salty and delicious (especially the olives!), but the best, of course, was last: the salted caramel budino.

I cant say that I didn't enjoy my dinner because I did. After doing our tria class ( another review) we decided to reserve a table at the infamous 13th st spot. 

This place was on fire from the moment we walked in . tip # 1 make sure to have reservations. 

We were sat a two top right next to some not very nice queens who complained ALL NIGHT LONG btw. We tried not to let the convos there were having about other peoples clothes, shoes, hairstyles etc ruin our evening, was kind of hard to do since there were legit less than 3 feet away from us. 

We started out with drinks ( I had been quite the drinker at happy hour and decide another glass of wine might not hurt) French of course sauvignon blanc.... Very lush and delish..  Chris did a brew dogfish aprihop.

We split the margarita pizza - toppings were perfect and this was just the right size to be an app for us. Cheese was yummy and just stringy enough. The crust could have been a little crisper but I enjoyed it none the less. Chili oil and fresh oregano was a nice touch. 

I did the sardines. The flavors of fennel and olives along with the sardines were melt in your mouth good. Be warned there are BONES . I learned a trip in Italy that helps get rid of those pesky things. If your not a in the mood to pick I would suggest not getting the sardines but I enjoyed them very much.

Chris did the chicken which came on a bed of risotto that was soooooo good I could have licked his plate. He said the chicken was super moist and seasoned very well.

I was stuffed and so was Chris so we passed on dessert even though ive heard nothing but great things about the budino .. we'll have to save it for another time b/c we will def be back.

Every time I eat something with truffle oil, I feel sophisticated. Am I the only one? I guess this is dumb, because truffle oil is just a foodie fad, really, and it'll probably disappear off of trendy restaurant menus in a short matter of time. How will I feel grown up then?

The uovo pizza at Barbuzzo was delish. Perfect to split for two, perfect with a glass of red wine, perfect to eat carefully as you watch the chefs prepare food at the kitchen bar. Drippy with egg and cheese, topped with brussel leaves for a lovely texture, this pizza was wonderful. The crust was thin and chewy, albeit a tad soggy on the bottom due to all the drip...

(Oh, shit. I totally just looked up "guanciale," the mystery ingredient. It's a type of bacon...prepared with pig's cheek, or jowls. Jowls? I'm going to pretend I never knew that.)

One thing that bothers me about "small plate" places like Barbuzzo- they always push the food, hard. Our waitress at the bar suggested 2-3 plates per person, but for my friend and I, one pizza and one dessert was absolutely satisfying.

The salted caramel budino was perhaps one of the most delicious desserts I've ever eaten. Dark chocolate crust, layered with room temp  vanilla caramel and a dash of sea salt. God. I can still taste it.

"It's like a cup of dirt!" said my friend Kate, referring to the childhood treat of chocolate pudding and Oreo crumbs. "Only for adults." 

So much for feeling sophisticated.

Four years later and Doma still delivers a delicious bowl of bibimbop, a very nice Korean taco, and a welcoming atmosphere!

The only misfire was the pork bao bun, which lacked that sweet-sauce I expect with a bao bun and the meat-to-other ingredient ratio was off (a lot of meat), so the texture didn't feel right.

PS. Doma receives bonus points for responding to e-mail inquiries whilst closed for the holiday weekend!

One of the only restaurants in Philly we've found to serve okonomiyaki, Doma has a very pleasant atmosphere/decor (super-comfortable banquet seating) complete with polite (and cute!!) waitstaff.

Very good bulgogi bao bun (they no longer serve pork belly bao buns, FYI), though the pickle was kind of a strange addition (in my opinion). Practically perfect miso soup (including enokitake mushrooms!). The bibimbop was sizzling hot in its stone bowl with a tasty kochujang sauce. Heard good things about the spicy tuna roll in particular from my fellow diners.

This is a pretty darn good sushi spot. Since moving to Philly over two years ago, I have not had decent sushi. I tried a few spots in the West Philly/University City area. All were mediocre at best.

Like I often do, I took to Yelp to find a better sushi spot. Doma had good reviews and seemed to be a reasonable distance. I ordered up a Zipcar, than my food, and off I went.

When I got home I was giddy like a school girl. I got the Sushi special and added some eel sushi. I gobbled down the miso soup. It was pretty good. Than, I went at the sushi. It was so tasty. Nice and fresh just how I like it. The ginger to clean my palates between sushi was very refreshing. Everything was perfect.

No longer do I need to eat mediocre sushi, because now I can turn to my new sushi best friend, Doma.

I'm not a fan of repeat dinners so close together  since there are so many great places to try however after my last review my food baby was stuffed to capacity ad I did not have enough room for the salted caramel budino. I was crushed because I really wanted to have something sweet after. Alas Sunday date day we bopped in hoping to find a seat at the bar or at the open kitchen. 
Open kitchen had 4 empty seats and we scooped up two right smack dab in the middle. Though I had already had two glasses of wine at tria I opted for a third ( WHY NOT ) the boy got a beer and we perused the menu. Since we had nibble on two cheeses and bread already we just went straight for entrees. I chose the pan fried gnocchi and my "date" got the margarita pizza. The first time dining here I didn't try it with the Chile oil that it comes along side but it was ah-mazing. The gnocchi's came out piping hot sans pancetta and were unbelievable. It was like eating small clouds swimming in butter. The apples gave the dish another form of texture which I am a huge fan of.

I shared my dish to make sure I had room for the budino. I had seen it created for a few other tables but the anticipation was killing me. One budino two spoons and orgasmic mmmm's and ooohhhhs followed !
Chocolaty cookie crust 
Some sort of creamy mouse 
The sweet caramel topping -
SEA SALT 
Each bite left me thinking about ordering another. I hadn't gymed it since Thursday so I blocked that thought and just savored the sweet bites.. until the bowl was empty.

(to the tune of "Wildest Dreams" by Taylor Swift)

He said "Let's get dinner this week
But let's stay in the city, don't care about the crowds."
I thought, "Good lord, I know just the place"
Haven't been in forever... but this is gonna taste real good.

The dim lights, it's cozy as hell
They do Mediterranean well 
And with that tartare, our meal it begins 
My one condition is....

Say you'll save room for the... caramel budino
please, don't try to say no, babe....
Dark chocolate crust, oh gee
Say you'll save some room for
The dessert you've seen in your.... wildest dreams (ah--ha)... Wildest dreams, ah-ha.

I said "No one's gonna know what we do"
We ordered just a small plate... then we decided on two
And the pizza's a familiar treat
Nothing last's forever, especially burrata.

Full bellies, we're cozy as hell
They do everything so dang well 
And even though we both feel quite stuffed 
My one condition is....

Say you'll save room for the... caramel budino
please, don't try to say no, babe....
Dark chocolate crust, oh gee
Say you'll save some room for
The dessert you've seen in your.... wildest dreams.

There's nothing I've eaten here that hasn't rocked my world. It's a great spot for a pair or MAYBE four, but wouldn't go for a large group. Barbuzzo is a sexy, warm spot for intimate conversations over shared ricotta and enormous, delectable stuffed meatballs. The portions are always larger than I remember, but rarely do we have any leftovers regardless!! Their gnocchi is the best I've ever tasted, and everything you've heard about the Budino is true.

From their spotless, beautifully designed bathrooms to their exquisite service (ever present somehow without hovering), Barbuzzo is just another feather in the cap of the Safran Turney dynasty.

Securing a reservation on a weekend for primetime at Barbuzzo takes you almost as long as it does to heal a broken bone in a cast. I find small sharing plates romantic and fun, so Barbuzzo was right up my alley. 

Dining Partner and I were seated towards the front against the wall. Like Lolita, this place is close-quarters. We started with the sheeps milk ricotta cheese, which I would equate to spreadable heaven on a lightly toasted baguette. We then had the stuffed meatballs, which in hindsight I probably could have done without. The lemon ricotta tortellini was a creamy melt-in-your-mouth bliss. We devoured the Maiale pizza. Of course we had the salted caramel budino for dessert. Everytime a new dish came to the table we wondered if it would be better than the last, and it was. Our server was great and we left stuffed to the gills. Can't wait to return.

The food here is good with a variety from Japanese to Korean. Service is so very friendly. Restaurant is BYOB.  However, the restaurant overall is not very clean and needs major updates. Starting from the clear chopsticks that are too worn out and is like toy chopsticks. Plates and bowls are a bit dusty and has some small particles on it. Restaurant has a lot of potential and I'm hoping there will be some improving over time.

My review is going to be no different from everyone else.. Barbuzzo is amazing. Its so good, that this is my first time eating a full meal here, after living in the city 6 years, because I can never get a reservation or walk-in at a reasonable hour! 

So, hope for a bar seat, or make a reservation weeks in advance. The place is tiny, and fills up quick. 

Once I came here at sat at the chefs counter and ordered a delicious pizza. That's all I ate since it was so hot from the oven, we ate our pizza and left. But last week, I scored a table and sat down to enjoy a nice full meal.  The CAULIFLOWER was delicious, baked, with some sort of creamy cheese or sauce, with artichokes. Yumm. My favorite dish was the WHIPPED RICOTTA which i was licking the plate to finish. Had a really good balsamic glaze on top, and the rustic thick slides of bread were perfect for dipping.  We also had the OCTOPUS, which was so delicious, but actually my least favorite the way it was prepared in a salsa-type style. But the octopus itself was charcoaled flavor and cooked perfectly.  Lastly, the GNOCCHI was amazing, huge mushroom pieces and truffle sauce. I loved this dish. 

Bravo Chef, your unique menu items makes me want to order one of everything. And every bite I tasted I couldn't get enough.  Highly recommended to anyone, if you can stand to be cramped seating after a long wait, or lucky enough to score a reservation. Service is great too, very friendly and helpful wait staff.

A haiku to profess my love for barbuzzo:

Sheeps milk ricotta
Salted caramel budino
Return visit soon.

Seriously, this restaurant will be high in my must-oft-return list. 
the dishes that i had were good, the presentation is quite nice, the space is friendly, accessible and tasty wine and drink list, and i love the counter where i can watch the cooks at work.

they need to work a little on the temp of their wood burning pizza oven.  and please stop charging for bread.  

simple elegant food.  the ladies of 13th st have done it again.

Despite our less-than-stellar Valentine's Day experience we came back to the mid-town location with 7 buddies Saturday at 7:30. Due to the fact that they do not take reservations, we were worried a bit that we wouldn't be seated. However we called ahead and they said they would do our best to seat us when we arrived. We only ended up waiting a few minutes. 

For drinks, the Capri Cooler in pouches and the Aviation cocktail seemed to be popular in our group. We decided tapas was the best route, everyone picked their top choices and passed them around. We ordered Cheeseteak egg rolls (and we finally received them!), chicken lettuce wraps, scallops, fried calamari and shrimp, lobster mac and cheese, jumbo lump crab pad Thai, BBQ chicken quesadilla, and the french onion soup dumplings. All plates were easily shared between the nine of us and we were all satisfied. The french onion soup dumplings were a favorite, but only after they cooled because THEY WERE HOT!

Service was very quick and attentive thanks to Randall our waiter. He really did a great job and seemed like he was genuinely enjoying himself. 

Several dessert flights were ordered and they were all very good.  The s'mores, liquid chocolate cake, and peanut butter/chocolate were table favorites. A 3-flight was perfect to share between two people. 

*Despite the fact our table was more the 6 people, gratuity was not added to our bill. Good thing we double checked rather than assume it was. Service was 5 star and we wanted our tip to reflect it!

Continental Mid-town is one of my go-to spots in Center City. It has offerings to satisfy picky/safe eaters, foodies, and those who love fun cocktails.

My favorite is to go for lunch, which tends to be more reasonably priced, either for the Continental Cheeseburger or the Continental Salad. Other crowd pleasers: the Lobster Mac'n'Cheese (with orzo!), the Astronaut cocktail, the Rad Na Thai Chicken, and the Korean Pork Taco.

One thing to note: when I dine in for dinner, I generally substitute out the chicken and substitute in the seared tuna for the Continental Salad; however, when I ordered take-out this evening the request had to be manager-approved and then when I went to pay the receipt was swapped at the last minute for one with a $10 price increase after confirming "which kind of tuna" I was getting (not sure what the other option would have been...). (All I'm saying is that it would've been nice to at least have been notified of the price difference.)

Love the Mütter Museum, a museum of medical oddities.  Who would have thought something like this would even exist.  Certainly not for the faint of stomach, and I always chuckle at the thought of tourists walking into this museum without knowing what it is.  

There are skeletons, a wall of skulls, all sorts of strange (and gross) things in jars like fetuses and organs.  There is a gigantic colon (a horror story to tell your child that won't go #2) and a whole filing cabinet filled with different swallowed items.  Last time I was at the Mütter Museum there was a mummified body, but I don't remember if this was a traveling exhibit.  

I wish there was more written about each exhibit, some of the exhibits have back story and information about what you are looking at, others are just sort of... there.

I also wish it were bigger.  It is two rooms, but the second room is packed floor to ceiling.

I first became a fan of Rex after Philly Mag's Battle of the Burger and it has been on my to-eat list ever since that glorious September evening. We came here for brunch Sunday when they opened at 11. The restaurant's atmosphere was polished and sophisticated and I felt a bit out of place in with my hangover, sweatshirt, and jeans.  Dining Partner and I both ordered the chicken and waffles benedict. The chicken was crispy, maple-ly, and delicious. The waffles were light and fluffy and the egg was cooked to runny-yolk perfection. I had a side of salad and dining partner had the homefries. We saw at least 6 other chicken and waffle dishes come out to other tables, it's really a hit! We both cleaned our plates. I also ordered an iced tea which I didn't think was too troublesome. Our waiter said the first one he made was a bit weak, so he was brewing a second. It tasted fine, but probably could have used one more teabag. When he asked and I told him this he ended up taking it off the check, and explained they brew each iced tea by hand individually. It wasn't necessary for him to take it off the check since I drank the whole glass, but I appreciated the gesture. I will be back for the burger and fried chicken!
This place maybe disturbing, but it has a ton of interesting displays. If you got a strong stomach and don't mind the macabre, then go here to see some wild stuff

If you know what you're in for and want to go, this place is 5 stars.

Although a bit smaller than I thought, they still manage to pack all of the bizarre and strange. Dot be lured into LA's Ripley's Believe it Or Not. The real stuff (I mean jars of bones an pieces of organs that are preserved) is here. 

Ever seen Texas Chainsaw Massacre? This is like that guy's basement after the guy from Hostel redecorated it.

Don't miss: the skeleton of the twins.

Red meat. It's back in my life.

And the burger at Rex1516 was fabulous. Onion marmalade and bleu cheese? Hell yeah. I pushed the bacon to the side and jumped right in.  The roll was so soft. It was homey, just like the atmosphere. 

Heirloom tomato salad was disappointing. There was probably a 4:1 ratio of red onion: tomato and the cheese was barely there. Would not get this dish again, unless they halved the price. Right now it's $10, which seems outrageous. 

Service was great and the atmosphere is old timey and cozy. It's a fun dinner spot for sure.

I took my girlfriend there after my most recent deposition and let me tell you..... It was excellent! We were there in time for happy hour so we decided to try a few things. Everything we got was so good. The French onion soup dumplings are one of the best things I've had at any restaurant! I highly recommend those and the BBQ chicken quesadillas. 
Aside from the food the service was awesome. The bar tender was attentive and very friendly! Now there were only a few people at the bar but he managed to get us all involved in conversation and with some cross over between patrons! 
Overall I thoroughly enjoyed going here and will be back!

If you are going here you need to order the shoe-string fries. If you are going here in the summer you need to head to the roof for NYC partying.

As many of you already know, this is the place to see and be seen, even though it is not one of the newer establishments. The bar has some very attractive city dwellers and tasty concoctions.

Giddy up! Rex 1516 is the goodness. My baby mama, no drama, aka the wife, took me here for Father's Day. It was for brunch, and it was some good Southern Cooking.

There was much to choose from, and that means reasons to come back, but on this visit I went with the Chicken and Waffles. Now this concept, in of itself, is pretty fantastic if done right. I've had it before at several places, but never like Rex 1516 does it.

This was done a la open face sandwich. At the bottom, you have Belgium waffles. Expected. Then, you have boneless friend chicken. Well of course. But then. Wait for it. Wait for it. You have poached (fantastic) eggs (yes yes yes) with a creole (woah!) hollandaise sauce (yup, Carlton dance time!).

I mean, like, wow, this was some good stuff. Like, really, really, really, fantastic, great, good, good, gooodie, good.

But there's more.This came with breakfast potatoes, as they call it, also known as home fries to some. This gets real special because you can get the sweet potato version. Yeah, I did. And, oh how sweet it was!

Gosh. Oh gee. This place was so so good. I want to go back to there!

Since my move to Philly 4.5 years ago, this is the cultural organization I have visited the most! Anytime I have friends from out of town visiting, this is always one of the first places I suggest visiting. In addition to the rotating exhibits they have each year, I don't ever get bored with the fascinating medical oddities and beautiful architecture of the building. Also LOVE the renovated medicinal garden outside. On a nice spring day, I would recommend just sitting out there enjoying the beautiful plants and soaking up the sun. 

I know that others have complained about their strict policies but I can understand why they're strict. It's the nature of the elements in the museum and building. Also, the museum space is a bit crowded, so it makes sense that they aren't comfortable with folks carrying/wearing large, oversized stuff. I haven't ever experienced any negativity in their customer service here though...and you know I'm a huge customer service snob! Everyone has always been super kind and friendly. I will continue to support this wonderful organization.

A decent and reliable option in the middle of Center City, I have visited a couple more times since my first review - both times as kind of a last minute option for two hungry folks. The last time we stopped by, it was very close to where we were and was later in the night. We opted for a booth and ordered a few small plates to share. French onion soup dumplings, some type of fresh Caprese-like plate with these amazing breads, and lettuce wraps. We shared these plates and were fully satisfied. And there's something to be said about the fact that this restaurant is owned by the notable Stephen Starr. From the kooky appearance and decor, one would judge the place to have average food. These dishes we ordered were actually pretty damn good. Especially that specialty dish they were offering - Caprese thingy. It was SO good. 

Anyways, The Continental is a good choice - open late, decent drinks and good food.

met a friend for happy hour. when i worked in rittenhouse, i always walked by this place and never gave it a second thought. the outer appearance leaves very little to be desired. well, my friend said that they had decent happy hours so i checked them out on yelp. from the photos i saw on posts, i wasn't impressed with the interior decorum with the weird pods for chairs and stuff...it's all very kitschy i suppose.

anyways, we decided on this place because it was easy. when we walked in, we were greeted by a friendly hostess. we opted to head to the second floor bar because it was empty and quiet. since we were the only ones at the bar when we got there (it was def not empty when we were leaving-the opposite, they were getting quite busy), the bartender acknowledged us right away and i was impressed with their drink list. their happy hour specials are indeed pretty nice - they have a few cocktails for $5 which is pretty amazing (they're good sizes too), they had some beers and have a variety of snacks to choose from. i was able to get two sangrias for $10! i left there spending $15 for two cocktails (tax and tip included!!!). the bartenders were great, always checking on us when drinks were low or empty and letting us know about last calls. also, there was a cute barback ;) that always helps, right?

don't judge a book by its cover - i would def make my way back here for happy hour again...i'd also like to give their dinner menu a try.

this review is a bit delayed...i went to the mütter september last year, when i first moved to the city. it's such an interesting place with so much to see. my friends and i spent about 2-3 hours when we went. they also have a medicinal garden outside. the gift shop has a lot of cute souvenirs and the museum provides some interesting talks and events. i've been wanting to go again, but haven't had the time. when and if i ever do, i might get a membership!

Of all the wonderful museums and history we have in this city I think this one takes the cake. I wouldn't eat a full meal before going there. You may not want to eat a full meal after either. 
A full museum of oddities, surgeries, and wounds. I'm salivating already. 
They have an awesome civil war wing. It shows battle wounds and surgery tools. 
It's not the biggest museum but I could spend a lot of time there. So I suppose it's all about what interests you. 

Check it out if you're into weird shit.

2020 has thrown some curve balls, but Rex 1516 continues to hit them straight on!

With COVID-19 on the rise, we decided to give thanks as a couple this year, with help from Rex 1516's Turkeyday package for two: Smoked Turkey Roulade, Andouille & Cornbread Stuffing, Smoked Brisket Shells and Cheese, Buttermilk Biscuits, Chanterelle & Green Bean Strudel, finished with Sweet Potato Pie with a pretzel streusel and buttermilk whipped cream.

We picked up the evening before and used the reheating directions to get everything piping hot for dinner on Thursday. Everything was delicious: I think I could live on the stuffing and here's to my first sweet potato pie!

While I hope we're able to dine with our larger family/friends dinner(s) in 2021, I'd be happy to give thanks "with" Rex 1516 again if needs must.

Happy holidays, all!

Rex 1516's Turkeyday package for two was so delicious, we decided to celebrate Christmas with its package for two, too: White Bean Stew, Ham, Gravy, Stuffing, Biscuits, Au Gratin Potatoes, Bouche de Noel with Raspberry Coulis, and cookies.

We picked up the Christmas Eve day and followed the reheating directions to get everything piping hot for dinner on Christmas Day. Everything was delicious: I could eat the raspberry coulis on its own and those chocolate chocolate chip cookies were so fudge-y!

Happy holidays, all!

Later-weeknight, post-awesome Yelp Fit Club spinning session at Body Cycle after a long work day guided us along South Street to Rex 1516, where the kitchen was about to close (thank-you Mondays), but when our party of five walked in, they were graciously accommodating. As a newbie to the restaurant, I didn't recall reading about their burger, but as it was exactly what I was craving, and theirs read well off the menu, I took a shot (with their sweet potato fries) and...devoured the entire thing. One of the best burgers in the city: piping hot, cooked perfectly to order (medium, as I tend to choose medium until I know how well a restaurant's chefs will execute a meat order) and incredibly flavorful--rivaling/equal to Good Dog's burger...plus, I think I preferred the slightly thicker-cut sweet potato fries (not quite steak fries, but not shoestring either) and Rex 1516's aioli was perfection. Fellow diners raved about the pot pie and the mac'n'cheese and the charcuterie board looked pretty awesome. Will definitely return and will bring friends!

Rex - The Royal is as stellar as its predecessor, Rex 1516, now in a larger, beautifully decorated space. Loved the cozy booth our four-top was seated in (from which we would've had a perfect view of the small stage, had it been a live-music night), being able to peek into the kitchen to watch our food being prepared, and the service, which was friendly and knowledgeable.

Definitely recommend coming hungry and with a small group of fully-vaccinated* diners, so you can taste all the offerings! We started out strong with a few appetizers and sides: Hush Puppies and Okra Fries (okra tempura, fried shishito, long hot comeback sauce), Fried Green Tomatoes (jimmy red corn meal, house pimento cheese), Skillet Mac and Cheese (cooper sharp cheese, smoked provolone, gruyere, cavatappi, garlic breadcrumbs), and Buttermilk Biscuits (pepper jam, honey butter). All four were spot on and the hush puppies, fried green tomatoes, and buttermilk biscuits sang to our diners who used to live in the south.

For our mains, we enjoyed (with no complaints**!) the NJ Scallops and Fall Succotash (NJ sea scallops, pumpkin, turnip, butternut squash, sunchokes, corn, crispy kale, brown butter), Frogmore Stew (fish, mussels, shrimp, andouille sausage, potatoes, corn, spicy old bay brodo, grilled sourdough), Chicken and Dumplings (grilled chicken breast, smoked chicken leg, sweet potato dumplings, green meadow farm mushrooms, roasted vidalia onions, pepper jus), and NY Strip Steak (14oz. sustainably raised NY strip steak, grilled green meadow farm mushroom salad, crispy salt potatoes, compound butter). The Frogmore Stew had a wonderful flavor and heat to it, and the andouille sausage was particularly tasty.

The drinks were well-named and generally tasty: Spotted Lantern Fly (cacao washed whiskey, cardamara, lemon, honeycomb, aqufaba), Royal Sazerac (vieux carre absinthe, templeton rye whiskey, cognac, demerara, bitters), and Sorrel Loser (sorrel, clove, allspice, lime, ginger, sparkling water). Note, the Sorrel Loser has a very strong taste, which was not to the liking of all at the table.

Cannot wait for our next meal at Rex - The Royal!

*Proof of vaccination required for entry.
**The only hint of wistfulness about Rex - The Royal, is that the fried chicken formerly served by Rex 1516 is no longer on the menu--perhaps it will rotate on sometime in the future!

Poppin bottles with the ice like a blizzard ...... 
Well thats sort of what we did armed with 3 bottled of bubbles we descended on Cafe Lift.. to get well lifted.
There were six of us so we had a slight wait but once we were seated it was on ! 
I decided on the tomato frittata with pesto. The frittata was  overflowing with asparagus , mozzarella cheese and tomatoes then  drizzled with pesto pretty much a party in my mouth. The egg dish came along side a few (i do mean a few) roasted breakfast potatoes and toast. The potatoes were pretty good i just wish there was more a little more taters on my plate. The only downside to brunch was the cash only business luckily KP never hesitates to have a bank roll on her and i downloaded the pay pal app so i could repay her pronto.
Will i be back oh yeah

I am constantly impressed by the execution at The Dandelion! I've been a few times since my 2013 review, mostly for lunch, and their sandwiches and homemade chips are just perfect! This past business lunch, I had the Dandelion Turkey Club sandwich, with the most amazing (but not overpowering) garlic mayonnaise, nueske bacon, vine-ripe tomato, avocado, and fried egg. The bread was outstanding, perfectly toasted, light brown in the center, slightly darker on the outside. I wanted to eat every bite, so I did, practically ignoring the terrific hand-cut chips, which were a lovely color and perfectly salted. This is the second time I've had that sandwich, which remains one of my favorite non-burger sandwiches in Phialdelphia (maybe even my favorite!).

PS. Complimentary sparkling water is always appreciated by us seltzer lovers!

The Dandelion serves a fantastic burger, 'nough said. OK, a little more to say: the sear on the outside was succulent and the slaw and the "special sauce" were perfect finishing touches!

Oh yes, and the deviled eggs (obviously a popular item by the number ordered by the tables around us, too!) were just as I would make them (who doesn't love deviled eggs?!). We especially liked the beet garnish on the oysters, which set them apart from run-of-the-mill.

This is a cool breakfast spot that was much needed for the area. My girlfriend and I got there, and the place was packed.....yikes. We got there and the hostess was able to seat us at the counter instead of a table. That's cool, minus the snug fit and uncomfortable seats. Our waitress was nice though and attentive. She made sure we had a enough coffee in our mugs. The food was a bit of a wait, but the place was mobbed. I got the PB & J pancakes and that was pretty amazing. The cakes were fluffy and the PB &J was a great sweet topping. I didn't even need maple syrup for it! I enjoyed my time here and hope to return for a table.

I came back for the food.  Superb.

First of all, the food really hit the spot.  My special lady friend and I shared the deviled eggs, she had the scallops, I had the rabbit pie, and we shared a side of string beans with stewed tomato.  The deviled eggs were okay, they had me wishing for the Sriracha deviled eggs at barcade, but they weren't bad.  The entrees were amazing.  The rabbit stew was home cooked goodness, a nice flaky top with hearty stew underneath.  Her scallops were out of this world.  Apparently they have a lettuce/parsley sauce, which is mild and blends wonderfully with the light taste of the scallop.  The beans were good, still had some stiffness to them (which I prefer).

I really dig the homey look of this place.  It reminds me of Christmas when I was little, with tables and chairs stuffed into every corner to accomidate the number of people who will be attending.  I didn't mind at all that our party of two were stuffed into a corner where we had to move the table to get up, in fact it added to the charm and intimacy of the place.

Service was attentive and friendly. 

We ordered a couple of cocktails with dinner, a Pimm's Deluxe and Nosey Parker.  Their signature cocktails tend towards the sweet side, next time I'll likely order something simpler.

I'm not sure how I've gone so many weeks searching "Brunch" on Yelp and not managed to eat here yet. It should be at the top of everyone's to-eat list. I'll start my review by saying Cafe Lift's location is best described as a diamond in the rough, not far from Callowhill on 13th street. My dining partner and I walked in around 11am on Sunday morning and were seated almost instantly. This was pleasantly surprising due to the fact that the place was packed and many groups of 3+ were waiting to be seated. The service was excellent with quick, attentive, and friendly servers. I ordered the breakfast burrito sans mushrooms while my dining partner ordered the French Toast topped with fresh fruit and a side of whipped cream. Both were fantastic and priced under $10. I will for sure be back at some point for the cannoli french toast, because it looked amazing. 

Hey management, if you're reading this...it would be awesome if you throw a waffle on your menu. I have full confidence it would be spectacular.

Dock Street was our very last stop after about 8 hours of Erin-Expressing. I've never been so far west in West Philly.

Once glance at the menu and it was settled. Three of us would share the "Sicilian" pizza, which was in no way like your standard thick, square-cut tray pizza. Super thin and crispy, this giant pie was topped with olives, capers, walnuts, roasted garlic, sun dried tomatoes, mozzarella, red sauce and basil. HOLY FLAVOR. 

Same goes for the completely unnecessary cocktail I ordered, which was a mere $5 and made with sriracha sauce and oranges. A bloody Mary of sorts, for the night time hour. 

While pies run a bit steep ($18.50 for our large), that wood fired taste is absolutely worth it. Dock Street is my #1 reason to return to West Philadelphia.

(I was challenged to write this review to the tune of "Higher" by Creed. Blame him, not me. CHALLENGE ACCEPTED!)

When dreaming... of all that makes brunch amazing
Mind goes to... this cafee-eehh-ehhhh.
At sunrise, can't wait to walk on in
I never wanna leave the comfort of this place
Yes, there's a hunger, yearning for some bacon
Every day that I'm awakeeeeee.
So let's go there
Try to beat the rush
C'mon, let's go there.
Can you pass the pancakes?

Lift will take you higher.
French toasts makes some blind men see...
Lift will take you higher...
And it's found on 13th Street.

They offer breakfast all day long
Helps me to appreciate
Those noon French toast dreams...
But my friend, don't sacrifice the savory
My god those eggs, they're heavenly, I could scream!
Cash only, but worth it
Your love will replace all hateeeee [of the atm fees?]

Lift will take you higher.
French toasts makes some blind men see...
Lift will take you higher...
And it's found on 13th Street.

This spot is a gem. Unfortunately, not a hidden one, and if you come too late, you'll be waiting in a long line with all the rest of the brunch-bunch. But, seriously: it's worth it. Delicious, not a long wait, the smells alone are ALMOST worth the trip. Keep your eyes on the rotating French toast specials, and the huevos rancheros everyone raves about are worth the hype. 

10/10 would go again. Can't even wait.

service = great

staff = hot

food = ok | pizza = delicious

beers = good esp the ipa

beer selection = decent

i've been wanting to stop by since moving to west philly a year ago. finally had the opportunity to do so. my friend and i were hungry and didn't really wanna do local 44. we had orig planned to share a pizza but when we got there, we changed our minds. she did the fish and chips. i did the burger. the food wasn't great, but it wasn't bad either. the reason for the 4 stars then? their staff, beers and atmosphere. the host and server were both very friendly and nice. didn't hurt that they were easy on the eyes.

my friend did a sour beer i think and i did an ipa. the beers were good. service and environment were great. i'd def walk on over here again!

Great for groups. I really enjoy hanging out here. 
Wait staff is always friendly and on point. 

Do yourself a favor, order the cheese burger pizza.

Enjoyed myself.  They make a pretty good cocktail, the ambiance is nice, the crowd seemed appropriately calm for the atmosphere (except for the group of girls who came in half an hour before close and wanted a round of car bombs).  The food seemed very interestesting, I'll be back for that and some more drinks.

dock street is my go-to for last minute happy hour sessions with friends. and it never disappoints.

they have rotating beer options and the options are always pretty good. at my last visit, i got their plum pale ale. OMG, SO good! it wasn't too sweet and it wasn't dominated by the plum. also, very smooth and easy to drink. 

everytime i go, i quickly glance at the menu, but that really is a formality. i always end up getting the same thing, fig jam pizza. full disclosure: i'm not a big pizza fan. i'd much rather have something else...well, not here! the pizzas are perfect i can eat them everyday if i could. i've had others like the sausage and flammenche(sp?)...all equally delicious. 

service has also always been nothing less than fantastic. so grateful for you dock street!

(to the tune of "Hands to Myself" by Selena Gomez)

I want this beer to myself
No, you can't have a sip of my brew.
I want it all to myself.
Just go and get one that is for you.

Won't even give you a taste
This glass is sticking to me like it's glue
My refined palate won't waste
Would rather have this than gin and juice

Oh, 'cuz all of the salads and pizza
They're gonna be just for me-za
And I'm trying, trying, I'm trying, trying....
But every bite brings me closer
Share my cheesy goodness? A no, sir.
And I'm trying, trying I'm trying....

But this beer is for myself.
Keeping this beer to myself.

Is bogarting all the beer greedy? Maybe. But with a few rotating taps and some great seasonal specials, I don't mind being a bit greedy. I've been to Dock Street during Baltimore Avenue Dollar Strolls, for late night pizzas, happy hour, and dinner, and I always leave satisfied. Though all their beers aren't home runs for me, there's always at least one that's really gonna knock my socks off. The pizza is unique and delicious. It's not cheap, but it's not prohibitively expensive, and the ingredients are high quality. From a cheeseburger pizza to buffalo chicken, to one featuring seasonal vegetables and a mustardy sauce, they're bringing out the big guns in flavor, and I couldn't think of something better to match with all that beer.

The crowds... are plentiful. From couples to families, college kids to yuppies, hipsters to hippies, Dock Street is nearly always full of a diverse group. But the service is attentive, the space is typically clean and bright (if not always open, crowds and all), and the product is DELISH. Will be back again and again, worth the trip to West Philly.

Cafe Lift on North 13th Street just south of Spring Garden, occupies the first floor of an old factory in this almost up and coming neighborhood south of core Center City. It's decor is all early 20th Century post industrial.  This has it's charm with high ceilings and exposed pipes and ducts, and large photos of the local buildings in black and white that are strong suggestions of it's history. 

On Saturday morning it was packed with a 20 something crowd enjoying Rival Bros Coffee and a short, but tasty breakfast/lunch menu. Hard walls make for poor acoustics, and the din was several decibels above comfortable. But, everyone was friendly and dealing with the racket. Even the queue to the single restroom had cool people who understood the situation and willingly chatted with their line mates.

Our table wait was about 25 minutes, but we made it to a small deuce in the middle of the room, with people on either side. It was tight, but the ambient noise allowed for privacy. The menu was divided into brekkie and lunch on either side of the document. I went with the chicken salad wrap, and DT opted for their burger. Both we're good. The burger seemed hand packed which gave it a softer texture and more retained juices. I prefer a more chunky chicken salad, but had no negs about theirs. We were drinking the house java, which was hot and kicky, but served in small white cups that needed refilling after a couple of gulps. Larger joe vessels would have been more efficient for the staff and felt more generous to the customers. 

Cafe Lift is a very interesting place to hang out. The room is really humming and the staff works hard to please. The harshness of the sound makes the experience not completely ideal, but that is overcome by the quality of the people and the kitchen, not to mention the enjoyment of just being in an old urban factory that has been so well repurposed.

I've only ever been here once. Stopped in while my shirt was being tailored. Let me tell you... the food was excellent!
Only reason I have not been back is I'm rarely in that area. At least not for breakfast. 
Service is great. The look and feel is great. The food was top notch. 
I look forward to a triumphant return.

move over sabrina's....i think i have found a new brunch love.  
part of me didn't want to write this review, because i'm selfish.  i want to keep this place all for myself.  but i can't help it.  i can tell you that since i've been here, i've been telling everyone about this place.  it's like when you're in a new happy relationship and you want everyone to know and you can't stop thinking about it.
well, that's me and cafe lift.  the food--amazing...anything from sweet to savory (how bout those lemon ricotta pancakes?!?!?!).  coffee--la colombe.  dingy warehouse setting.  and you can sit at the counter and have a very zen breakfast on your own.  it makes getting up worth it.

Oh, my. The power of a Yelp review.

Just a few days after my misfortune at The Franklin, I was contacted by the owner of the bar, Michael Welsh, who offered his sincerest apologies regarding the incident. I was truly in disbelief- he said he'd like to make it up to me but offering a round of drinks on the house for myself and the other six kids I was with that night. Of course, I accepted.

We rolled up to the bar, excited and curious about how things were gonna go down. We were greeted by Michael and seated right where we had sat before. "Back to the scene of the crime," Michael joked.

We even had the same waiter, who we loved and I can't say enough good things about. Please, if you can, request Rich as your waiter at The Franklin. Tell him what you like in a drink and he'll surprise you with the most elaborate cocktails, on the menu and off. In fact, that's what we did all night. "Rich, I like rum and fruit. Whaddya got?" "Rich, I like whiskey and bitters. Whaddya got?" 

"I'll have that!" was probably the most frequently used phrase of the evening. 

My group was also given a collection of snacks. There is no bar menu per say, but I think you can just ask for them. We had pork rinds, perfectly roasted pistachios, and a small jar of pickles that had been given to the bar from Supper.

We were also informed that the negative manager who treated us poorly on "the night of the crime" had been let go and it had been a long time coming.

My second experience at The Franklin was full of class, taste and delicious drinks. Many thanks to the staff who completely changed my previous opinion about the establishment.

Franklin Mortgage Investment Co. AKA "The Franklin" is as good as it gets for center city top quality cocktails.  I've been here several times, and love so many things about this place.  For starters, its hidden, tucked down the basement level of 18th st, don't bother looking for the sign, its too easy to miss.  Look for the bouncer, yes, it's that fancy.  The bouncer will make sure there's an open table, and walk  you in.  If there's a wait, you wait outside.  No lingering around, no standing room only.  It's so nice not to have inconsiderate people leaning over your table or bumping into your $14 drink.  

The place is tiny, small and narrow, but very cute.  Pre-prohibition style cocktails means you won't find vodka at this bar.  Unfortunately, I'm a huge vodka drinker and bourbon, whiskey, and gin are not my cup of tea (which is the Franklin's specialty).  However, I love their tequila drinks, so that's good enough to please me!  Trust me, you don't want to drink more than 2 anyway, or you'll be stumbling out the front door. 

The drinks are small, strong, made with a million ingredients, and the best liquid your taste buds will encounter.  So sit at your table and be patient, the drinks take a little while to make.  But hey, perfection takes time!  Also, don't come hungry, they don't serve food here.  I think they have peanuts. LOL.

Seriously, if you are into fine cocktails, mixology type fancy drinks, you cannot pass this place up!

Bud and Marilyn are my two new best friends. If I could spend time with them every week I would. The ambiance at their place is cozy and comfortable and the food is quite yummy. It's hard to order when everything on the menu is appealing. Let me give you the breakdown....

Reservations fill up quickly so make them in advance. We came for brunch at 11am on a Sunday. The cheese curds- amazing especially with the ranch sauce.The cinnamon bun- amazing and HUGE we split it between 7 people. Our server Michael, was fun, energetic, and very helpful. I came for and successfully received the fried chicken bucket. It's no lie, it's a bucket full of 1/2 a bird and shoestring french fries. It wasn't my favorite fried chicken of all time (see Alla Spina), but it was pretty darn good. We didn't have enough room for dessert, but anywhere that serves funfetti cake has a special place in my heart. When I ordered an iced tea I was mildly weirded out that it was just a bottle of honest iced tea priced at 4 bucks. So keep that in mind if you're an iced tea drinker.  I can't wait to return again, and again, and again.

Here is the deal, in the morning, as early as 7am, you can enjoy coffee and pastries at the bar or 2 tops, along side the carefully curated shelves of knick knacks and wooden accents. Happy Hour begins at that same space at 4pm with just a sample of the food offered downstairs. After 5pm, you can head down the stairs for a loooong menu of skewers and sushi. 

But for lunch (and that's 10pm-3pm), the menu is pleasantly streamlined: pick a protein (steak, shrimp, pork, chicken, tofu, meatball) and what form you would like it in (salad, banh mi, rice, noodles) in exchange for $7.

I do like a salad with minimal leaves and lots of herbs. South East Asia gets it. The Double Knot lunch salad is mostly citrusy cabbage, daikon, mint and cilantro.  Four lightly fried, plump shrimp came with it. It could work as a light lunch or shareable lunch appetizer.

I remember a few years ago when Sampan offered lunch, specifically the high quality banh mi they served. Double Knot brings it on back with a fresh baguette that doesn't hurt the jaw (some banh mi bread does!) and nicely marinated steak that steals the show.  The daily punch was a light melon drink that worked so well with both the salad and the banh mi. That's the thing with this menu, since everything is mix and match, it all has to make sense together, and it does.

Pretty good, "hip" speakeasy style bar.  The drinks were great, but not the kind of place that I would just order anything and be certain of it's deliciousness.  

I would recommend steering clear of any drink with Mezcal in it, unless you know what you are doing.  Even in drinks were it seemed that Mezcal was not the primary alcohol, it was an overwhelming taste.  Our first round, the other three people I was with ordered 3 different drinks that had Mezcal (often listed as the 5th or 6th ingredient) and all tasted primarily of Mezcal.  

I ordered an Old Fashioned and a variation off of a Manhattan.  The old fashioned was good (made with Buffalo Tract bourbon), though I'd prefer Hop Sing's.  The Manhattan-variant was very good, even better than the old fashioned.  I wish I remembered what it was called... it did have a burnt orange peal, if that helps.  

Its a classy place; clean and stylish.  Bouncers were friendly and apologetic about the short wait out in the cold (though a line quickly formed behind us).   

I wish they structured their menu a bit differently, if you are just wiling to try anything, the menu is fine, but if you have a preference towards certain liquors (which I think most do), it is a slow process to go through the list.

One does not simply.... walk into Bob & Barbara's. Not to say that it's anything like Mordor (though Thursday nights, there could be a few more flames than the average dive bar).

You have to go into B&Bs with a certain attitude and a handful of expectations. Know that if there's a line out the door, there's going to be a line for drinks. Know that you should be carrying a wad of cash, not a stack of cards (though not too big of a wad, drinks are silly cheap). Know that the decorator's last name is probably Pabst, as the walls are covered in PBR kitsch and knick knacks. Know that the bathrooms are minimal and the citywide specials flow like water.

If you go in with all of that in mind, you're gonna have a good time. 

If you go in expecting attentive service, a classy and clean joint, or quiet clientele.... well, you're gonna have a bad time.

The drag shows weekly might not be, IMHO, worth the $7 unless you go on the earlier side and plan to stay for a while. But if you roll up with a nice buzz already going around 10:30, well you've got a whole night right there. The $7 used to cover your first drink, though now I think the ticket they give you is only worth $1.50 off a drink. Take that as you will.

I'd say, if your expectations for fanciness are low and your alcohol tolerance high, Bob & Barbara's is the place for you.

Amazing, delicious noodles.  Its a small place, (you'll most likely need to share a table) but stick around, because people eat and get out quickly and the food is well worth it.
Try the duck noodles, tasty duck, broth and noodles.

My friends and I ended up at Bud & Marilyn's by chance as we were going from bar to bar after our dinner. This was the one restaurant we went to where there were actually some seats at the bar, so we stayed here the longest.

I ordered a patron and pineapple and was told that they had neither item, but the bartender offered to make me "a really awesome margarita" which I agreed to. It was indeed delicious.

The staff here were very helpful and friendly and my husband and friend took advantage of the $6 beer and a shot special. I didn't get to try any food here, but the folks on Yelp seem to like it a lot!

Overall I really enjoyed the cozy, dark atmosphere of this bar and would definitely return again - for a night of drinking or eating.

This is what a dive bar should be! As soon as you walk in, it is like a museum for PBR with all the advertising and other Pabst memorabilia. The place is very cheap with 2 dollar PBRs and 3.50 for that as well as a shot of Jim Beam. The bartender was the usual old school surly type that you would see in this place. The jazz band was also a nice touch of playing different cover songs. This is an awesome bar when you do not want to spend all your cash and hang out in a time capsule of the 70s!

Bob & Barbara's really does deserve that last star.  The jazz on the weekends is great, and my primary reason for coming.  It would be great if there were fewer people sometimes, but it probably wouldn't be the same.  

Probably the best dive bar that I've ever been to.  There should be old men playing jazz and blues in every dive, always.

$3 for PBR and shot of whisky.  I can't imagine ordering anything else here. 

Pretty awesome jazz trio playing on the weekend.  

Cash only.  

That's it.  If those things sound good, you have a reason to go to Bob & Barbara's.

Bud and Marilyn's is definitely another Marcie Turney and Valerie Safran success! It's the epitome of comfort food with plenty of fried and flavorful options and very nice service (sounds like we had the same server as Melissa P.!), as we definitely picked a Ben's brain about his favorites and what we should get as a group of 4.

Loved the Nashville buns: totally flavorful and spicy! The Fried Cheese Curds were also delicious (along with their two dipping sauces, one quite smokey), though I wouldn't liken them a mozzarella stick, as some have--they have more of the texture of fried tofu with that outer skin rather than breadcrumbs. Unfortunately by the time I got to my actual "main course" order (fried chicken with biscuit and pickles), I was pretty full. The chicken was extra crispy, which was nice, but definitely took second place to the buns in terms of flavor. The biscuit was lovely and the jalapeño cornbread was divine! Knowing I was going to be too full for a heartier dessert, I ordered the honey grapefruit sorbet. Having grown up with homemade grapefruit sorbet, I found Bud and Marilyn's a little too sweet for my taste--I love the zing of grapefruit; however, a fellow diner who doesn't like grapefruit enjoyed it, so maybe it's meeting the two worlds in the middle? The taste of chocolate peanut butter mousse (visually much like their salted caramel budino) was fantastic: I could totally see hunkering down with one at a movie fest and loving every bit of it! Will definitely return.

The "city wide special" (Pabst Blue Ribbon can + shot of rotgut whiskey) may as well have been made for Bob & Barbara's. To me, this is less of a bar, and more of a clubhouse for Soul music preservationists and counter-culturists. Every night has a theme, or a band, and the vibe in here is welcoming.

No question, B&B's is a dive. Still, I'm bothered when so many people throw that word so frivalously about a bar with so much going on. It has the best jukebox in the city, one of the finest bands in the universe (as Melissa pointed out), and more character than Eddie Murphy in Coming to America.

One of my absolute favorite haunts in the U.S. of A.

(To the tune of "Shut Up and Dance" by Walk the Moon)

To veer off the music, the reason this spot isn't getting 5 stars is two fold:

1. The Chop Suey, tasty at first bite, by the end felt like a saccharine, never-ending rice bowl. Not in the good way. I wish it were a smaller portion, OR they cut out a little of the sweetness? 

2. Our server kinda lost interest in us once our last plate was placed in front of us (I truthfully think he was deeply interested in the gentleman a few tables over. the flirtation was off the chain. We actually were interested in ordering another drink, or at least a shared dessert. However, he left us for over ten minutes after our last plate was cleared, and by then digestion has ruined any hunger left. Bummer, that funfetti cake looked dank.

I love the atmosphere. I love the lighting. I didn't even mind when the old-fashioned "lock" on the bathroom door failed to work and I was walked in on (oops) because everyone just seemed to laugh it off. It just promoted a great vibe.

I can't WAIT to come for happy hour. And to try more dishes. And maybe next time, I'll go specifically for dessert. Because this girl loves her funfetti more than some (distant) family members.

Great addition to the 13th Street dynasty.

My fiance took me here for my birthday dinner and I love this place. We arrived here and I just dug the ambiance of the restaurant. It had that very 60s vibe to it with wood paneling of the bar and that velvet paintings around the restaurant. I always enjoyed that retro look even though I am not from that era. The staff here is very friendly, and someone was willing to fix our wobbly table.

The food here was amazing to say the least. We started off with the pretzel rolls as an appetizer. They were crispy on the outside, but so soft on the inside. I decided to get the fish fry as my dinner, and that was great. I got two  big pieces of fish with fried potatoes, rye bread, and coleslaw. Everything tasted greated, especially the coleslaw! I am usually not a big fan of that stuff. We also decided to split a funfetti cake, and loved it. It was a huge piece, but shocked how light it was. It also was not too sweet. This was a great restaurant to celebrate my birthday!

I came here with 6 others on a Saturday evening around 8pm. I had the scallion pancakes to start which were delicious. For my entree I had hand drawn peanut noodles which were simple yet satisfying. All others at the table were very happy with their various handdrawn noodle dishes. It's BYOB so it's a fun place for groups and the bill was super cheap! Can't wait to return for more.

I dined at Bud & Marilyn's last week for my friend's birthday. We decided to come here on a whim, so without a reservation, we were unable to sit at a table, but we found plenty of open seating at the bar and chefs counter. 

This place blew me away! And my birthday friend as well.  We both were very impressed with how delicious everything was! You know when you take a bite of something, and its so good, you just look at each other with a mouthful of food and go "Mmmmmmmygod!"  Well that was everything we ate at Bud & Marilyn's. 

- CARROT appetizer stole the show. Our favorite dish of the night, was like artwork on a plate, and tasted even better! There was an amazing yogurt sauce, and everything else on the dish was perfection to my taste buds. Best carrot dish I've ever eaten! 
- Nashville HOT BUNS were also really good. The buns were delicious, and although I don't like spicy food, I gobbled this down easy and loved it. 
- SCALLOPS main dish was amazing. It was larger than I expected, with tasty corn cakes sandwiched in between the scallops. Very tender and juicy, the orange sauce didn't overpower the delicate scallops. Everything was just right. 
- Side order of some local GREENS was our least favorite, but still very good. 

Save room for dessert, seriously. Don't skip dessert!  We sat at the salad/dessert chef's counter so got to see each dessert prepared, and damn they were superior. We ate the Birthday confetti Cake, which sells out quick! It sounds simple, but the coconut icing layered in between that funfetti is fantastic and tasted sooo much better than I anticipated.  We also ate the chocolate MALT BALL cake, which is layered with a thick, rich, peanut butter filling. I would have liked more malt flavoring in the chocolate cake, instead of just malt balls on top, but the peanut butter layers was rich and delicious. The ELVIS dessert looked the best, I have to try that next! Also the lady behind the counter said her favorite was the coconut cream pie, which also looked mind blowing. FYI, these cakes are MASSIVE, so be prepared. 

I can't wait to come back here, everything was absolutely delicious and really blew us away! One of the best dinners I've had in a long time!  Oh, service was fantastic too :) All around perfect experience.

So how many times do you have to hear about how great a place is before you check it out? In our case 3 . Date nite started out in a great way cocktails at the bar. It was like opening the door to the 1920s . Everything about this place is upscale from the decor Which features plush booths and dim lighting. Feels like the bat cave in a sophisticated way. We opted to actually sit at the bar. We chatted with Katie who mixed up our awesome libations and provided us with sheer entertainment . I tries the dolly rocker Ah-mazingly good I'm a gin fan and alternatives to gin and tonics are always fun . Chris got the stemwinder to start he's infamous for force feeding me shots of patron. I wasn't offered a taste but that was fine by me. Next onto the Mexican firing squad and the el diablo. The firing squad came with a ginormous ice cube I thought that was a fun twist . It features pomegrante syrup which I had never even heard of! This tequila cocktail packs a punch but in a good way. El diable was really refreshing , had that warm sunny day kind of feel. You could throw backa few of them and not feel it til the next day.


We've decided to try one of the punches next time were in the area. 
My hats off to Katie who was super friendly and made the start of our night great.

This is what comfort food should be.  Comfort food does not need to be dripping with grease.  The cheese curds are a good representation, something that is typically really greasy was light tasting.  Better than the Cow and the Curd.  They went well with the chile salsa.  
The roti was pretty good.  I don't think they are as good as Banana Leaf, but this isn't something that you often find, so I'd recommend it.  
Of the starters that we ordered, I think the best was the Nashville buns.  The fried chicken was very good, and made me second guess what I ordered for an entree.  The soft buns with the slaw make for a terrific little chicken sandwich.   
We also had a side of creamed brocolini, which was far less creamed than a lot of other places would do.  You could taste the vegetable instead of just cream.  

I tried two entrees: The pork chop and the Tout special that they had that day.  The pork was a thick chop, with a sweet and tasty sauce on top of greens and grits.  This is a great, home style dish.  
The trout was served with brussel sprouts, bacon, and barley.  This dish worked well, and deserves a spot on the menu.  The brussels, bacon, and barley would make a great dish even without the fish.

The two drinks that I tried were well made.  The Sloe gin fizz wasn't too sweet (I really like that more places are making these).  The Gimlet slush was tasty, but not entirely my thing.

Very much enjoyed our Double Knot dinner! A little dark, a little funky/broken-up in design, the table where we sat (downstairs) was terrific for conversation--we could hear one another, even though sushi was being rolled and hot food being cooked just behind us and we were surrounded by other diners having conversations.

Though one of our diners is celiac and also vegetarian, we were all 4 able to do the Chef's Tasting Menu (10 selections + a mochi for dessert)--there were enough gluten-free/vegetarian (GF/V) options to completely satisfy!

Would definitely order again:
Cold: Hearts of Palm Salad (yuzu, scallion, radish), which was one of the GF/V dishes and fabulous, fresh, and bright.
Small: Pork Gyoza (relish, scallion, ginger) and Pastrami Pork Belly Bao (Russian dressing, smoked mustard, cucumber). The bao bun was the winner (for me) of the evening, though the pork gyoza came in second, as it was somehow baked into a scallion pancake--best of two worlds!
Robatayaki: Tokyo Scallion and Short Rib. I first had robatayaki scallion in Japan, and this lived up to it--such terrific flavor! The short rib was also great--very tender.
Sides: Crispy Brussel Sprouts (shishito, fish sauce, crispy rice)--definitely an example of brussel sprouts done right!
Sushi/Sashimi: Spicy Tuna Roll.

Other dishes we enjoyed:
Cold: Albacore (scallion, onion ponzu, radish).
Specialty Sashimi: Yellowtail (ponzu, soy-ginger, finger lime).
Crispy: Japanese Fried Chicken (daikon, kew pi mayo). I prefer Korean fried chicken, which is twice fried/twice as crispy!
Small: Edamame (salt), Shishito Peppers (aioli, chili, lemon).
Robatayaki: Asparagus, Enoki Bacon.
Meat: Duck Bibimbap (soy glaze, rice, egg). I found myself wishing there was less duck and more rice/vegetables, though I'm sure I was the minority.
Fish: Crispy Whole Fish (smoked, Tokyo scallion, pickle). Overall very nice and light!
Dessert: Matcha Mochi.

PS. The Monekys Fist (sake, coconut, pineapple syrup, lime, chili) cocktail was well received by the diner who ordered it, and fellow diners who'd initially scoffed thinking it'd be too sweet tasted and thought it delicious.

Enid C. has it right. 

Pork Soy Sauce Noodle, Shaved. 

It was textured to the bite, lots of surface area to pick up and hold the wonderful sauce; a large bowled experience with Ground Pork, mild Chili Flavor, Cilantro cooked into the mix, and enough liquid to cover every nano of the free form Noodles. 

Did it change my life as suggested by Enid?  The jury is still out, but the fact that they are taking so long to decide is definitely a good thing.  

I am hooked!  Just added 5 or 6 spoons of Sesame/Chili Oil from the table container, and the taste exploded in my mouth. 

When a joint has over 800 reviews there is little left to distinguish one from the rest.  Short and sweet (In this case more spicy) is the way to go.
Just giving an update - I've been MANY times since then and EVERY bite has been divine. Service attentive. This is a five star joint for sure.

This place is amazing! We ordered the chef's tasting menu, and allowed the chef to make the choices for us.  I had a hard time hearing the server, so I don't know exactly what everything was, but it was all delicious.  Some of the dishes made me rethink long held beliefs about ingredients that were used.  The Salmon and the

Tuna: was served with avocado.  Very fresh, very tasty, not as bland as tuna can be.  

Salmon sashimi: Absolutely amazing.  The best single bite of the night.  It was marinated with ginger and who knows what else.  It was fantastic.  Make me a hundred of these.

Pork dumpling with a crusty top thing:  Maybe it was the gyoza, I am not really sure, but the dumplings that we had were quite good and not your standard dish. 

Scallop and Flank steak Robataki: The pair worked really well together.  The scallop was one of the best things that I've eaten in a long time.  Two hefty sized scallops cooked perfectly.  

Duck Bibimbap: served with a runny egg, the egg mixed with the rice and duck worked very well together.  I would have preferred some more vegetables in there, bibimbap is usually jam packed with vegetables, but this was still very good.

Swordfish: Hands down the best swordfish that I've ever had.  Served in a soy sauce based marinade.  A very nice texture and taste.  

Brussel Sprouts: Tasty, I was hoping for some other green, as these are pretty standard these days.  It was a good dish, but I would try one of the other greens the next time I come.

My wife decided to take me here for my birthday dinner, and it was an amazing experience. We arrived a bit early for our reservation, but we got seated downstairs 5 minutes before it. The restaurant has a very intimate feel with dim lighting and great woodwork. It is a nice place to have a romantic dinner.

Our waitress was great and was able to walk us through the concept of the menu. I decided to get a cocktail since my wife said they are known to make good ones. I got the Savory Knot and it was a great whiskey sour like cocktail! The food was very good as well. The food here is small plates, so sharing is a must. The best small plates were the duck scrapple bao buns and the tuna rice crackers! Great food and atmosphere!

I am so in love with this place. It's this weird mish-mash of americana in the 60s or something, done in this lovely upscale way. 
So first off, GET THE CHEESE CURDS. They are literally the best little fried pillows of goodness ever. EVER. 
The rest of the food is just as kitschy-cool. Standouts for me include the biscuits that came with the fried chicken. The pupu platter, besides having a fun name, is just a great share platter. 
Skip: the chop suey. I'm not so sure how it ended up on the starters side, as it's like a giant bowl of bibimbap-esque-thing. Not sure how to share, and the flavors weren't as cohesive as the rest of the dishes I had.
The drinks are killer. Witness the cannonball, a bohemoth of blue that I definitely felt the next morning. Or maybe it was the amazing funfetti cake, which I could not stop eating despite being so full.
Service was just meh. (And seriously, what's up with the whole not letting you transfer for bar check to the table if you are waiting for your reservation?!)

But go. Get the cheese curds. And drink.

I FINALLY got to eat at Double Knot! I've been waiting forever, there's ALWAYS a wait, and Open Table is always booked, unless you want to dine at 10pm. 
However, there's some interesting things I figure out. The main floor is first-come-first-serve tables, so you can stand around and get the next table when someone leaves. The downstairs basement is actually the formal seated dining room, and much more romantic setting. Those tables you need reservations. However, there are A LOT of bar seats downstairs. The sushi counter is very long, with a lot of seats, and there's another bar in the back with seats also. So, if you don't want a table, you can probably sit at the counter/bar with no reservation. 

The food at Double Knot is some of the most fresh, melt-in-your-mouth seafood ever. My Favorites are: 
1. Edamame Dumplings - wow. I can't even explain how amazing these are. Delicate and delicious, melts in your mouth.  
2. Ahi Tuna App was so fresh, you hardly need to chew it, it was amazing. 
3. We had a rainbow roll that was on special, it was very fancy and not prepared like your traditional rainbow roll at any other sushi restaurant. This was much smaller, but very unique and fresh. Delicious!
4. Duck Scrapple Bao Bun was very good, I think this probably is the best bang for your buck, since all the other dishes are very small for the high prices. 
5. Eggplant small plate was really good, but only had 1 eggplant on a skewer, so we ordered 2. 
6. Brussel Sprouts were really good, actually a huge portion size. 

Everything is very tasty, but in general, most dishes were too small for the prices you pay. I went with my sister, and we probably ordered 7-8 plates of food before we got full. Our bill (including a $40 bottle of sake) was $160 for 2 people. Add tax and tip, and we paid over $100 each for dinner. That is too much for me!

I am a fan! Yes, I really like this place ever since a friend took me in 2008 or 2009. We would refer to the place as "shaved noodles" even though we prefer hand drawn because shaved noodles is just too chewy and hard to pick up with chopsticks. The old location when we used to go was small and super crowded for most of the day. But because of it, it brings about authenticity and you somewhat travel to a location in an Asian city with good cheap food.

What I like about this place is the freshness of the noodles and flavorful broth. The soups are just hearty and plenty for its price. My favorite to get is always sliced beef noodle soup. A friend of mine would always eat the noodle with pork soy sauce, which is also good. The menu is worth exploring considering the strange name for things like "U Toy  with Oyster Sauce." I did asked what it was but the lady had trouble explaining it to me. 
 
I am happy they relocated to a bigger space, but sometimes I wish they would accept credit card, especially when I'm around the area and do not have cash on hand. So I would often have to go to the other Nan Zhou noodle place next to the fire station. :/

i needs a real job and not my current indentured servitude status to fully enjoy this place.

its beautiful.  its dark, high ceilings, and large booths.  i love it.  i feel like i needed to whip out my mad men-esque costumes.  or maybe my flapper dress.  

but the bartender made me feel comfortable, even in my t shirt and flipflops combo, on a random early sunday evening.

the drinks are tasty and strong (and pricey!).  and they'll make you drinks off the menu.  and did i mention tasty and unique?  so yes.  i could sit there all night, nurse a drink, and feel glamorous.  so go go go.  enjoy yourselves.  i'll need to save up a bit before i go again.

i freaking love this place.  wait, let me say that again.  i freaking love it.  for reals.  it's one of those places that i didn't want to review and keep it a secret.

i don't care if they treat me like i'm not asian when i walk in here. (seriously, they've never tried speaking chinese to me, even though they do to everyone else who looks even remotely asian...but i seem to get that a lot...)

for $5.50, i get a bowl (or take out) of some of the bestest noodles and broth in the city.  it's like home, only tastier.  and if you eat in, you can watch them make the noodles.

Space: still beautiful.
Skewers: still great and pricy. 
Sushi: some of the freshest and best quality in the city.
Drinks: I've had too many. And they're amazing.
The lunch special: one of my favorite lunch deals in town.
Service: still frustratingly the only thing not up to par with everything else that is great about this place.

Always down for some good Mexican, we decided to check out El Vez which has been hyped up quite a bit.

We started off with some guac and chips. It was near perfection. Lots of chips and guac, and the texture and taste were just right.

I got some shrimp enchiladas. They were fantastic, though on the small side. My wife got chicken enchiladas, also great, and also on the small side. We got some plantains to go with our dish and it they were delish.

We got chicken quesadilla for my daughter and it was pretty good. Thankfully, it was more than my 3 year old could eat and I had some as well. Without, I might have needed something else.

Everything was real good. The guac was a generous portion, but the entrees were too small.

I really really really really really love El Vez. 4.5 stars, but the prices are definatly too high for me to come as often as I would like... For a "casual" Mexican restaurant (unlike upscale Tequilas on 16th & Locust).  However, the food is out of this world, so you get what you pay for! 

The goat cheese guacamole is the absolute best guac I've ever eaten. It's seriously to die for, worth that $15!  It's served in a huge rock-like bowl so the portion size is big. Trust me you won't be disappointed. 

Other food items are all good: carnitas, ahi tuna app, entree sampler is a good option too.  All the food is finely prepared and garnished to the tee. 

Full page of margaritas and other drinks, margaritas are strong and served in martini glasses with a shaker (I love that!) 
But at $10+ bucks a pop, don't suck em down as quick as I do, or you'll get a rude awakening when the bill comes! 

Ps, get reservations cause every weekend there's at least an hour wait.  Usually a wait on week nights too.

Whether you come here for drinks, the fresh quac, or for a full meal of food, you won't leave disappointed. The ambiance is lively and energetic. I almost always end up spending around $50 for 3 drinks and apps. The drinks taste good and are strong which is sometimes oh-so-necessary after a long work week. The only thing that gets annoying is the wait and the crowd, especially when you're the one waiting in the crowd. But oh well, it's worth it every so often.

(To the tune of The Weeknd's "I Can't Feel My Face")

And I know, it'll be the death of me, but I just can't resist
When I see that guacamole, gotta try that creamy dish
But at least those chips are nice and warm, and salty as all hell
More tacos.... More tacos...

Waitress said "Don't worry.... About it"
She told me "Don't worry, there's more."
We both know I could go without it.
She told me "Go mad on some avocado-OH!"

I just stuff my face whilst at El Vez....
But I love it, yup I love it.
Oh, can't stop stuffing my face at El Vez
But I love it. Yes I love it.

And, like, sure the price is kinda steep, but why not treat yo self?
Ingredients tasting wicked fresh, so I pretend it's for my health
And that chicken tinga can't be beat, I think I'm deep in love
This I know... Yes I know.


Oh, a giant, brightly colored Stephen Starr spot. Like a moth to a flame, I couldn't stay away from the shiny lights, the rotating bicycle, and the promise of flavorful margaritas. If you're experiencing sticker shock, there are plenty of cheap joints in South Philly to nab some tacos, nachos, and 'ritas. But if you're looking for a spot in the heart of the city where the ambiance is positively glowing, the music is bumping, and the people are beautiful. From dates to business dinners, entertaining clients to girls' or boys' nights, El Vez always strikes me as a spot to see and be seen. Luckily, this hasn't resulted in questionable food. As enough has been said regarding the guacamole, I'm going to focus on something very special to me. The Chicken Tinga Open-Faced Quesadilla. Three cheeses, red onion, bacon, poblano crema (and, of course, chicken tinga. This dish is savory, crunchy, cheesy, rich, and exciting. 

Ours was initially forgotten by our waitress. And I thank my lucky stars that I reminded her after our taco plate had been cleared. Because I would take this tinga treat over a dessert any day of the week.

We did NOT have drinks, split the guac, taco sampler, and 'dilla, and I believe it ended up around $50. Not a cheap night by any means, but not outrageous. We agreed we were leaving full, but not so full that we hated ourselves. And that, IMHO, is a sign of a quality dinner out on the town.

First time back at El Vez since the pandemic and I was pleased to see the "mask required" sign right at eye level on the front door; however, once inside, the tables are definitely not socially distanced. We were seated in a corner booth and the nearest table was right up against us--one of our diners was touching chairs with a diner at the nearest table, and that was after we'd moved the booth table closer into the nook.

That said, the service was swift and friendly, the guacamole continues to be stellar--our table shared both "The Original" (tomato, onion, jalapeño, cilantro, lime) and the Tito Santana guacamole (mango, red bell peppers, jicama, habanero & serrano chiles), which had a nice heat to it, balanced by the sweetness of the mango and red bell peppers and cooled by the jicama--and the Macho Nachos (queso mixto, black beans, salsa ranchera, sour cream, pickled red onion, jalapeño, and chorizo) was as tasty as ever. Others in my group enjoyed the Mexican Chopped Salad (romaine, watercress, pepitas, tomatoes, chayote, corn, black beans, queso fresco, crispy tortillas, lemon-avocado dressing or cumin-lime vinaigrette) and a variety of tacos.

Looking forward to warmer weather to return to Philadelphia so we can enjoy El Vez al fresco!

El Vez is my neighborhood go-to spot for drinks and snacks. While it's a little pricey, these tend to be reasonable.

It has amazing mojitos (especially the guava) and the blood-orange Margarita is a great balance (not too sweet).

I always love the El Vez "The Original" guacamole (tomato, onion, jalapeno, cilantro, lime). The Cesar Chavez guacamole (Tomato, basil, onion, Oaxaca cheese and pasilla-balsamic sauce) is also tasty. I've yet to try the Tito Santana guacamole (mango, papaya, chipotle peppers, red and white onion) to see how it stacks up against Lolita's (my favorite in the city)...
